reviewText: I really hated this game.\n\nI bought it, downloaded it, launched it, and found myself plunged instantaneously into the Zone. I was alone. There was no tutorial, no introductory cutscene, no explanation, not even a basic explanation of how the game worked. I walked forward, and looked around. I was instantly shocked at the low FOV and uncomfortably floaty" mouse control. This was not what I was used to - my most played FPS is Team Fortress 2
date: closely followed by Fallout 3. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. was something else - something new. I was excited. I continued walking and came across three people with guns walking in the other direction. "STOP WAVING THAT THING ABOUT" one of them bellowed
recommended: while sticking his assault rifle up my nose. I pressed "e" (because by now I'd explored the options menu and rebound some keys) to speak to him.\n\nWhat was going on? That was a question that I'd ask myself a lot while playing this game. This guy told me absolutely nothing of interest

reviewText:
Gameplay
Stalker CoP is an open-world RPG survival shooter with 3 large areas Zaton, Yanov and Pripyat, very atmospheric with plenty of side quests that reward exploration.
The beginning of the game is tricky with hardly any equipment or money, there's no tutorials or any kind of help so you need to find your own way to survive, isn't an easy game
The A-life will not give up until you ran out of ammo or eventually die, some will trow objects at you     Screenshot  and even telekinetically steal your weapon, things appear randomly in the sky or mutants with camouflage   Screenshot   etc. Human opponents put up a tough fight, they kinda cheat in fog weather or at night even without nightvision scopes equipped, (but mods like Misery fixes that) so playind like CoD will get you killed.
Still includes the emissions and anomalies (detectors needed for finding artifacts  Screenshot  ) and more customization of armor/weapons.



Graphics
it features the X-Ray 1.6 engine supports dx11 elements like real time tessellation, shadows, wet surfaces, volumetric smoke and others like SSAO DOF... so in other words it looks good, models and textures are a little outdated but shadows and sun rays are amazing (i recommend to use mods like AtmosFear3 specially designed for sky textures and weather behavior ).
Screenshot


Sound
The background noise of the zone is enchanting. In the distance, the reactor is booming as before, animals roaring in the west, shootout in the East, everything draws exactly the image of the restricted area as you are used to it.



Multiplayer
has Deathmatch and CTF style competitive matches with its multiplayer mode. Mind you, this doesn't exactly represent the highlight of the experience. If you want to get the best out of this game, stick with the main campaign, for what it's worth.


Story
Call of Pripyat - takes place shortly after the events in Shadow of Chernobyl.
Having discovered the open path to the center of The Zone, the government decides to take control of it via Operation Fairway"
date: in which they plan to thoroughly investigate the territory before dispatching the main military force.\nDespite these preparations
hoursPlayed: with all five helicopters crashing. In order to determine the cause of the crashes
voteText: the Ukraine Security Service sends an ex STALKER agent
helpfulPercent: Major Degtyarev
votesHelpful: into The Zone\nAfter discovering that the crashes were caused by strong electrical currents
votesTotal: Degtyarev makes his way to an evacuation point located in Pripyat. Along the way
votesFunny: depending on the choices the player makes
commentsCount: he may meet a number of different characters that can become his allies.\nEventually
column16: after arriving in Pripyat
column17: Degtyarev's party finds themselves surrounded by the military survivors
column18: who take them to their base. Once there
column19: they work together with the military commander of the helicopter group in surviving and escaping The Zone.\nThey are met by Strelok
column20: the protagonist of the first game
column21: who offers his full cooperation including the reasons why the operation failed in the first place.\nDegtyarev then helps to re-establish contact with headquarters and
column23: organize a desperate evacuation out of The Zone. There are multiple different endings available depending on the player's success
column24: whether or not some of the characters survive the evacuation and how the lives of other stalkers Degtyarev met throughout the game turn out.\nIn the ideal scenario
column25: Degtyarev becomes head of the Security Service in The Zone
column26: and Strelok gives all the materials he found in The Zone to the government
column27: prompting the creation of the "Scientific Institute for the Research of the Chernobyl Anomalous Area"
column28:
with Strelok taking up the position of chief scientific consultant.


Bugs/Glitches
It has soooo many and it will crash or make one or two missions almost unplayable. i recomend to mod the game (some will make it worse lol).



MODs

MISERY: (for hardcore difficulty) its full concept modification that touches every game aspect including textures

column36: Recon and Sniper.Each comes with unique attributes like endurance

http://www.moddb.com/games/stalker-call-of-pripyat/mods?sort=rating-desc



Overall 8.5/10
It's easily in my top 5
Exploring the hazardous lands and scavenging through abandoned buildings with aggressive wildlife never gets old.
This is a true PC game ( not ported

reviewText: If Fallout New Vegas and Dark Souls had a baby, it could come out something like this. reviewText: I spotted the derelict ship, known by the local STALKER's  as Skadovsk, in the distance. A wave of hope passed over me. The Zone was cruel, unforgiving, and merciless. With the sky growing darker every second, the tension and anxiety building up, I made the final sprint to the Skadovsk. It was difficult to see at this point, with only the silhouettes of dead trees and abandoned machinery to guide my way. My flashlight had ran out of battery, along with my PDA. Navigation was close to impossible. I could feel the Zone closing in, with the sounds of the unnatural creatures this unholy place has birthed echoing in the darkness. I may have a weapon - however, it was badly damaged, and my single magazine of ammunition wouldn't do me much good, as my gun was unreliable and often jammed or malfunctioned. No prayer could change the fact that I was a walking meal for these creatures. Creatures, whose shimmering eyes you could see in the distance with no visible body, speeding across your vision. Whatever unnatural cloaking the Zone has given them, they could attack from any direction. I wasn't going to let them get that chance. The Skadvosk was near, now. I'm getting exhausted. I'm hungry. I'm thirsty. I had used my last bandage after getting shot by a bandit, if I wanted to survive, I had to get inside. Just as I approached the gaping hole in the hull of the ship, those piercing yellow eyes appeared in a cluster of dead grass. The eyes that followed me, watching me, waiting for me to slip up before it attacks. It was all I could see, the rest of the world was encompassed in a miserable darkness that could strike fear into a fearless man. Just as I had stepped inside the broken hull, sprinting with my last burst of stamina to the sealed door, ear-piercing shots were heard above me, along with the heart warming Russian insults being directed at the creature that was just hunting me. Stepping in the ship, closing the door behind me, I quickly unloaded my haul to Beard, the bartender and trader. The weight lifted from my shoulders, I purchased some Bread and Vodka with my newly acquired Rubles, and sat around the table, listening to my fellow STALKER's tell the tales of their own Misery.

reviewText:
This game makes you want to buy a ticket to Ukraine and tour Pripyat.  It takes the core concepts of the original game and pushes them in a direction that allows you to have a little more fun while exploring the brutal representation of a real-life scarred patch of earth.

The first game had a lot of elements of wanting to go somewhere, but the high radiation levels or heavy enemy resistance prevented it.  CoP opens up the world around you a little more and gives you some more room to do your own thing.

There are little touches that help crank up the entertainment level as well.  One of my favorites is the randomly occuring blowouts" that will almost always (without the appropriate inventory items) kill you if you can't find cover in time.  Some of the greatest moments in this game exist when in the middle of a vicious firefight
date: or at the final moments of a task that has you hurt and running low on supplies
recommended: and then a blowout starts rolling in.\n\nGet ready to feel like a badass.  Get ready to have moments where you're running for your life.  Get ready to drain hours of your life exploring the wastes.  Pripyat is calling."

reviewText:
Okay you little casual, listen here and listen here good.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is not your average 'Pew pew shooter'.  You need to realize this right here, right now.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. will ♥♥♥♥ you up. If you think playing Dark Souls or ArmA  prepares you for this game then I'm sorry for you.


In S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you will be thrown into The Zone (some people call it Hell and they have their reasons)  and you will be given an objective. Simple as that.  No tutorial, not any big baby hand-holding cutscene and no magic armor that defends you from everything.

You are literally one of the most useless things walking around in The Zone and of course the NPCs will treat you like one.  They will try to steal from you, kill you and even ask you if you want to die fast or slowly.  'Make your choice'.

What can you do to avoid that? Nothing. It will happen sooner or later because as I said you are the most useless thing in the game.  You will die at least 5 times within the first hour and if you are a dirty casual, you will abandon the game.

If you want to master this game though, you will continue playing and every time the game beats you up like you were a bag of trash.

So here are two tips from  an experienced player such as myself:

Tip #1 Take your ♥♥♥♥ing time, idiot.

You do not kill everything you see, because you can't.  You have a better chance waiting for your friendly" NPCs to kill each other and then go loot their bodies because that's all you can do at the start of the game.   You are pathetic.

So after you get some nice loot
date:
go sell it in Skadovsk. You do not know what Skadovsk is? Then open the ♥♥♥♥ing wiki and see for yourself. That's how you will play this game from now on. You will learn things from the damn wiki because it's the only place that explains things.

Tip #2

Do not go outside during night. I did once
recommended: and to this date I still wake up in the middle of the night from the nightmares.\n\nDon't go outside during night

Overall score:

10/10. And if someone gives it lower than 10

reviewText:
The vanilla game is good but for the full experience get the Misery mod through ModDB. You will die, you will limp away from skirmishes and fights with mutants, you will end up consuming Charlie Sheen levels of cocaine just to make it back to camp with a half beating heart to sell your loot for scraps, you will smoke more weed than Willie Nelson just to survive an encounter with poltergeists or controllers, drink more vodka than Courtney Love to cope with radiation, eat raw mutant flesh like Hannibal Lector to subside your overwhelming hunger, you will save every three steps, you will want to punch your monitor, you will probably take your aggression out on your spouse and/or kids but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it you enjoy every second while doing it because this is how a game is supposed to feel and how it's to be played. You will most likely release your bowels while venturing tunnels or the zone at night so make sure you get your diapers ready, the ambiance is unbelievable, the mod is very hardware intsenive but if your rig can handle it then its very aesthetically pleasing if you like dead trees, grass and half ♥♥♥♥♥ voice overs. Its also very likely you will develop premature stages of Carpaul Tunnel from looking every direction every .6 seconds to see if something is going to molest your face and dignity.

This game is highly recommended to anyone who is masosadistic enough to venture into the zone and struggle through every aspect of life.
15/10

reviewText:
A Paladin's Review: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat. A Polished Yet Stark Post Apocalyptic World.Genre: FPS RPG Post-Apocalyptic Horror Open World.
Developed and Published by: GSC Game World
Platform: Windows Only.
Business Model: Base Game.
Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
If Shadow of Chernobyl was the wild west of the STALKER universe, Call of Pripyat is the civilized" entry into the series. My immediate impression of the game is that it's much more polished
date: with refined mechanics and a much more stable world to explore. Its clear that the developers didn't want another buggy Shadow of Chernobyl again. However
recommended: there were trade-offs with this approach. Unlike the creepy and danger-around-every-corner feeling that SoC gives you
hoursPlayed: CoP comes off as a more stark and alien. As if this wasn't Earth anymore. The "living world" that was present in SoC is much more subdued and scaled back in CoP and some mechanics were removed to my disappointment. Despite my disappointments
voteText: they didn't overshadow the sheer fun surviving in the Zone. After all
helpfulPercent: what could possibly be more enjoyable than listening to glorious Russian accents
votesHelpful:
finding strange anomalies and surviving the mutants of the Exclusion Zone.

Combat Thoughts
The game is more complete
votesTotal: better balanced and more variety of weapons no doubt thanks to its focused development cycle. You can also modify your suits and weapons this time around was also a nice change
votesFunny: allowing for a much more RPG-like experience. My favorite gun had to be the railgun you picked up in the later part of the game
commentsCount: the sound from firing it was just too cool. Overall
column16: weapons feel very well balanced and have their own pros
column17: cons and punch to each weapon. Ammo is still pretty limited but there are more merchants to buy from so it's not terribly difficult to keep a good supply on hand. Everything is suitably deadly
column18:
requiring you to keep on your toes the entire time.

Exploration Thoughts
Exploration in this game is better and more rewarding. There are plenty of interesting areas to look around
column19: people to meet and creepy as heck underground structures to freak out in. I noticed more of the exploration took place out in the zone more than in underground facilities unlike SoC which had several notable X Labs to explore. That being said
column20:
there's still a creepy lab or two to get creeped out in.

Atmosphere and the World
If there is something to be disappointed about
column21: its the reduction of mechanics from the previous entry. Gone is how epic the A-Life engine felt when creatures roamed the lands and danger was around every possible corner. That sense of risk evaporated. In SoC
column22: you could come across battles going on or the aftermath. Also gone are the risks to the NPCs
column23: the zone changing around you on a regular basis with every emission. Any important quest giver won't be killed this time around which I felt was a damn shame. Gone is that sense of continual change that SoC had. In SoC
column24: factions fought each other over land and constant conflicts. When certain events
column25: those factions took advantage of the craze to get into all-out warfare. The Zone feels static now
column26: not as unpredictable as it used to be. It stays put for the majority of the main story. Instead
column27: it goes for more mechanical purity and straightforward experience. I can't blame them for going that route and I'm certainly not going to complain about it being a lot less buggy than CoP. However
column28:
I do wish they had taken the A-Life engine to a whole new level rather than step back.

PC Settings & Modding
CoP is largely clean of bugs in its vanilla state so modding isn't as required as it was in SoC though there is some. The expected PC settings are mostly here though you have to do some modding to open up Field of View options
column29: V-sync and borderless windowed mode. You can find more about that on PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com]. In game you have a selection of resolution options
column31: full screen on/off and sliders for gamma
column32: contrast and brightness. Advanced options include vision distance
column39: and shadow quality sliders. In fact
column40: there's almost nothing you can't tweak and change in the advanced graphics options. Everything from SSAO modes to volumetric light to NPC flashlights
column41:
there's a crazy amount of choices to optimize your experience. CoP is the best optimized game of the lot too so your computer shouldn't have too much trouble running it. There's only two audio sliders this time around for SFX and music which is a bit limited. Key rebinding and secondary keys are also supported.

Final Thoughts
The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. remains one of the most memorable series I've had the chance to play. The journey has been exciting
column42: terrifying and challenging all at the same time. Call of Pripyat is the least buggy and better overall game of the series. But
column43: I feel it loses that sense of risk that Shadow of Chernobyl took
column44: instead going for a more standard open world experience. It's still incredibly compelling compared to most open worlds though. I still want to return to the Zone again and tackle it again. Which is pretty rare for me to want to do with most open world games. What can I say
column45: it's a unique series. Its tragic that the development studio closed its doors. While GSC has been rumored to return
column46: I'm doubtful that we will see another STALKER game again. I definitely recommend this game if you're into the FPS
column47: RPG and post-Apocalyptic type titles such as these. Despite all of its flaws and quirks
column48:
the experience is well worth taking head-on.

reviewText: An absolutely amazing game with an incredibly oppressive and bleak atmosphere. Following the Chernobyl catastrophe, there was another explosion in the Chernobyl exclusion zone, an explosion that left the surrounding environment altered in ways that defy scienfitic explanation. The area is now filled to the brim with deadly physics defying anomalies, countless pockets of radiation and incredibly lethal mutants. The area is simply referred to as The Zone".\n\nThose that explore the zone
date: in search of valuable artifacts spawned from the mysterious anomalies
recommended: are called Stalkers. You are one of them. Or rather
hoursPlayed: you pose as one.\n\nYou are in fact a Ukranian army major
voteText: covertly entering the zone to investigate a lost helicopter squadron sent in to conduct reconnaissance in the zone. To accomplish your mission
helpfulPercent: you need to make allies with other stalkers and with their aid make your way towards the city of Pripyat and find out what exactly happened to the helicopters and their crews.\n\nOf course
votesHelpful: there's also hostile humans to contend with
votesTotal: ranging from bandits
votesFunny: brain fried zombies (Still capable of using their guns) and foreign mercenaries. You also have some degree of choice in which faction to align yourself with and every side mission you complete (Or don't) have an impact on the epilogue endings of the game. It is very much worth it to complete every side mission

column16: with a large emphasis on resource and inventory management. It also has a hunger mechanic
column17: which adds flavor without in any way becoming overbearing. There's a real time passage of time (At a factor of 1 minute per 3 seconds or so)

column19: which are essentially storms that turn the entire world red and fry your brain unless you take cover inside a solid structure.\n\nThere's quite a lot of weapons and armors to acquire and many ways to upgrade them to improve your survivability. You can also equip artifacts to boost various attributes
column21: increased endurance or resistance against radiation.\n\nI personally find that the equipment progression curve is a bit uneven

column23: which was prevalent for a large part of the first two games

column25: because it certainly isn't. Later in the game

column27: trying to scrounge for decent gear

column31: because there is quite a few of them. But

column44: 55 of 55 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The sequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, Call of Pripyat does an excellent job of adding to the previous game's mechanics and making it a smoother experience.  Issues from Shadow of Chernobyl such as item repair are now included without needing mods and other aspects are changed such as artifact hunting and a degree of neutrality with other factions (such as mercenaries and bandits).  The game is perhaps more open world than SoC and the side quests are much more intuitive.   Most importantly, the game retains much of its original atmosphere and you'll continue to explore the decaying wastelands of the Exclusion Zone.

With that said, the game does have some weaknesses.  While it retains that atmosphere that made SoC great, it also (disappointingly) leaves you cut off from much of its namesake town of Pripyat.  Regions you once explored in SoC such as the hotel, government building and the park with its iconic Ferris wheel are now only seen in the distance behind fences.  The buildings you explore instead seem sparser and more linear.  Likewise, human opponents are pretty thin in the game and most of your fighting will be against mutants.  Sure, you CAN just start shooting people on sight but the different factions and uncertain nature of SoC felt much more exhilarating to me and winning against 'human' opponents just felt more gratifying than shooting umpteen mutant dogs and pigs.  Finally, the ending felt rushed to me and less epic than the original breech into the forbidden CNPP.

Even with all that, Call of Pripyat still felt like a worthy successor to Shadow of Chernobyl.  I would definitely recommend that someone new to the series play SoC first but Call of Pripyat will be a satisfying way to remain in the mysterious world of the Exclusion Zone a while longer.  Call of Pripyat played well 'vanilla' without requiring mods (which is more than you can say for the buggy SoC) but there are multiple well crafted mods to dramatically change the world and keep things interesting for a long time to come.  Shadow of Chernobyl was a tough act to follow and Call of Pripyat made it most of the way there; a recommended purchase in my book.

reviewText:
Perhap's the most polished of them all, with a heck load of improvement's and solidness from the u-i to the gameplay.
Gameplay+ Spot-on atmosphere.
+ Option to free-play at end.
+ Combat is once again twicthy but solid.
+ Many new item's, medicine's and lil weapon's.
+ Improved hud & perhap's the best of them all.
+ Reward's really feel like reward's & have better loot.
+ Weapon's now really feel like weapon's & they hit.
+ Mini-map and world-map has once again been polished on.
+ A.i has been improved in many aspect's & doesn't bug so often.
+ Side-quest's have been very improved & made upon interesting.
+ Wearable's most better here due to option's of removing helmate's,more upgrade's.
+ Reputation system, you can side between 2 faction's which differ to different consequences.

- Game can be very-easy at the lowest-difficulty.
- Artifect's can make up for easier farming as they respawn upon every emmision.

Story+ Multiple ending's.
+ Each mission is set at a great pace & balance.
+ Just same old scary at time's but more better pacing.
+ Over-all story is more interesting as it's from a different angle.

- Cutscenc's are pretty sucky.

Design ( Graphic's ) Included+ Many improved-animation's.
+ Lighting improved on many aspect's.
+ Improved & responsive u-i and interface.
+ Finely-optimized can run on low-end rig's.
+ Over all area's are more better looking & planned.
+ Menu & the whole atmosphere is even more spot-on here.
+ All item's have nice-quality picture's as well more information.
+ All model's have been improved same for all the over-all aspect's.

- Many micro-stutter's in between.

Sounds( + OST )+ Sound's from enviromental to gun's are simply so pleasing.
+ Strange random sound's really add immersion.
+ Music is good-on & just fine.

- Voice acting is one of the more worser & purely laughable.

ConclusionMany improvement's & a feeling of being in a different zone, a whole-world of polishness & enjoyment is available here.

reviewText:
I love the STALKER games; they have an interesting setting and story, post-apocalyptic feel, interesting open areas to explore, lots of unscripted yet interesting encounters, horror elements, authentic industrial environments, and refreshingly unforgiving FPS gameplay.

Call of Pripyat is definitely the least buggy and most polished of the series. Extremely compelling, fun to explore, and just plain awesome. Also, many of the game's locations are very close to real-life locations in the zone, and they look impressively authentic when you compare photos to screenshots (which I absolutely love).

There are less side quests, but they are individually larger, more interesting, and better thought out than all the mini-side-quests in STALKER: SoC. The interface is also much improved from previous STALKERs, highlighting matching ammo when you mouse over a gun, for example. There aren't as many stashes, but the stashes in CoP can be found without knowing where they are beforehand. Artifact rarity is handled the best in CoP, compared to SoC (too plentiful and easy to get) and Clear Sky (nearly impossible to get). Emissions and equipment upgrades are the best in the series here, as well.

The story of CoP is very loose, to let you do whatever you want in whatever order you want, though it's not nearly as good as the story of the original SoC. The game's ending is similar in style to that of Fallout, where it shows you short clips about people and places in the game, telling you what happens to them afterwards. I felt like it was an epic and satisfying end to the trilogy. Ironically, though, the Pripyat area of the game was the worst in terms of well-thought-out-edness in story, dialogue, and missions/quests. Pripyat is, on the other hand, really awesome because the entire area is closely moddled after the Eastern section of real-life Pripyat, with the only major difference being that a service center building is in the game where a kindergarten building is in real life (that, and all the impassible video game fences" around the edges of the in-game area).

There is a very active modding community for the game
date: as well. My favorite mod for Call of Pripyat is 'SGM'
recommended: which adds a ton of content and improves the graphics.\n\nAwesome game. highly recommended if you like survival FPS games."

reviewText:
I've played through this game 3 times now and this game gets better every single time i play it.  The first two were on normal and the hardest difficulty but that just wasnt enough for me so i went and installed the MISERY mod to get the real ball busting experience.

How does one describe the greatest game ever made? is it the story? the world building? the game mechanics? the difficulty and responsibilities the game gives you to manage? the innumerable ways to play the game?  For all of those questions i would tell you to look no further than the Stalker franchise.  If ever a game was to be the flag ship of PC gaming THIS is the game that people should look at in reverence and awe.

Games of today hold your hand, coddle you and all but tube feed you because they dont trust you to anything intelligent  with their property....no mods, tutorials for everything and a streamlined experience so that nobody strays too far from the course like some sort of amusement park ride.  The Stalker games fly in the face of all of that and rewards you for being different and when everything that can go wrong does...finding your own way to survive in the Zone.

Finding secret stashes, managing your limited resources,  risking your life in Anomolies (elemental effects like acid, fire, wind and the like) and doing perilous quests that arent for the foolhardy.  You arent John Rambo and you dont run around with a fully automatic LMG shooting wildly like in most modern games. This game cements my love and facination with the true Survival Horror games like the original Resident Evil series before they started taking steroids.

You are just one man with fear in his heart, a deathgrip on your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ beaten up shotgun, a dream of seeing a rusted ship you call home and only a fistfull of shotgun shells to guide your way back in pitch black darkness.

This game is the most liberating feeling knowing that your life is in your hands and at any moment a mutant could two shot you from behind.....you live by the ability to stay level headed and just how many rounds you have left in your gun(s).   This game is my pride and joy please at least try playing it its well worth $20.

See you in the Zone, Stalker...

reviewText:
*Hackjob Ukrainian accent* I remember it like it was yesterday, the death, the mutants, the gunfights...
Boris and I just got back to Sadovsk from doing our latest scav run, it was hot, wet, and reeked of ♥♥♥♥. I sold my aritfacts, because apparently I could find millions of them and 97% of them were basically Ruble magnets rather than useful, but I didn't complain, then we set out and it happened....

Bloodsuckers, this horrible beasts that looked like Liza Manelli except the face looked like it was put through a meat grinder, ugly they were, uglier than Donald Trump's hair! They killed Boris and sucked him dryer than a transvestite going down on a rich client, it still haunts me, the sounds of them sucking on him as if he was a sodding juice box... Then they disappeared out of thin air, leaving a horrendous odor that would've made a burning tire dump smell like a rose garden.

To this day, I never leave safety without my anti-bloodsucker underwear.

Alright seriously this is a good game, as many people before stated it's got a great atmosphere and sound along with original music. My most loved gem about Call of Pripyat is that it captured my imagination of how Pripyat is now. (Believe me I know it's not really a zone full of anomalies and mutants, but it's my imagination and muck off if you think having an active one is bad.)

reviewText:
This game is a gem, seriously, It's really great.
The atmosphere is simply awesome,
A game that is not in the United States.
The night is mostly realistic and beautiful.
The guns are great to use.
You need to eat to stay alive.
The radiations and the environment (emission, radiations, etc etc...) will kill you if you are not careful
I could say a lot about the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. franchise but there is just too much to say, the game itself is awesome.
I'm also a fan of every Fallout games but Bethesda should really take some ideas from them especially in questions of realism.
It's not the greatest game in terms of open world but you probably won't even notice because of the game being so awesome.
Do I have to say that the thunder looks real great in this game?

I'd suggest this game to anyone who likes open world, post-apocalyptic, FPS, atmospheric, survival, horror, challenging  and semi-realistic games.
If you haven't played the previous S.T.A.L.K.E.R. then I would suggest you to play them, It's a real great series, you won't be disappointed.

9.5/10 for the whole S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in general.


Only thing that sucks is that we can't make all the characters in the game speak in Ukrainian and It's the same for all the S.T.A.K.E.R. games, when I play a game, I'd love when the characters speak in their language for a question of immersion.

reviewText:
Buy .... Install Misery ,, Cry ..... Go back to COD .....

A masterclass FPS.

I owned a retail version when it was first released and certainly got my moneys worth then. After purchasing on Steam after a bout of nostalgia it suddenly occured to me just how good Stalker C.O.P really is. In an age when developers are churning out massed produced rubbish designed to grab your money and run after 6 hours worth of banal gameplay ..... Stalker despite its flaws ( including constant stutter that you wont get rid of no matter how hard you try ) remains a classic, atmospheric, masterwork shooter .... add the Misery mod and experience some of the most intense gunfights you will ever see in a game. Better than Dayz. More intense than Arma ....

Highly Recommended.

reviewText:
Not a detailed review, just wanted to express my appreciation for this open-world survival game which I played for the second time on Steam.

Great atmosphere and weather, beautiful landscapes, nice story and side-quests too; game is not so hard on vanilla (you'll die a lot anyway) but that's how games should be, in my opinion... Challenging but entertaining at the same time.
Apart from some FPS' drops (I have an old graphic card, though), the game is bug-free, cut scenes are not the best but the ending pictures are very nice (they remind me a lot of Fallout ending style).

That's it, if you haven't done it already, go for a walk in the zone. You'll make friends and have some vodka :)

reviewText: Call of Pripyat is the best game in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. This has the best main plot with a Fallout 3-style ending that changes depending on your actions in game. Very atmospheric with plenty of side quests that reward exploration and help flesh out the lore of the locations. Has a lot of depth with gun play and survival mechanics, requiring you to eat food while in the field and keep yourself bandaged up to avoid bleeding out. Call of Pripyat stands on its own feet and doesn't require any previous experience with the series; a must play for any FPS fans. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=584128276 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=584133881

reviewText:
Im gonna skip the amazing graphics, sound, atmosphere and gameplay, and tell you the most important thing: this game has the best AI in any game to date. The developer was inspired by FEAR in terms of AI in battles: the enemies flank you, sneak up on you, take cover, give commands.

But this is not just an FPS, it is also an RPG, and HOLY CRAP! if this aint the best RPG out there, then please let me know! Thus, the AI extends outside of combat. Monsters travel in packs and engage in fights with other monsters and humans for survival's sake. If the fight seems to be in their favor, they will engage, otherwise they will fall back and move along. Squads of stalkers patrol the Zone: sometimes to defend their base, sometimes to recapture a point. Sometimes it's just one greedy stalker trying to retrieve an artifact from an anomaly so that he can sell it later.

And that's another thing about this game: artifacts and their anomaly counterparts. You see, this is the Zone. Radiation has chnaged many things, not just animals and humans. You will find these mini puzzles with an expensive artifact as a reward. Sometimes it's a timed electricity trap. Sometimes it's a gravitational anomaly that holds the ground and water up in the air in an unnatural fashion.

Marketing is killing the gaming industry nowadays. Sales people push developers to improve on graphics and numbers: more DLC, more weapons, more maps, more more more. And it seems like everyone has forgotten the other ingredients that make a game good. Such as AI.

If you haven't played this game yet, buy it now! I have spent most of my time playing STALKER: Clear Sky (cheaper), which puts more emphasis on factional warfare. But as far as I can tell, this one is just as good, if not better.

reviewText:
Here's to a Good Day's Work.
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat = Fallout + Deus Ex + Ukrainians

I know I'm rather late to this radioactive party, but I've finally revisted the Zone.

For those not in the know, Stalker is an FPS dystopic horror that is known for its open world exploration, scary mutants, and almost-RPG aspects.  This is the logical sequel to the first game, Shadow of Chernobyl, but you don't really need to have played the first to enjoy this one.

Call of Pripyat is set in a post-Chernobyl disaster area, the Exclusion Zone or just The Zone".  Although it's forbidden for anyone to enter
date: fortune-seeking scavengers known as "Stalkers" regularly find their way in to this cess pool of rust
hoursPlayed: and otherwordly death-traps known as "Anomolies".  They do this mostly to dig up "Artifacts"
voteText: strange new types of matter that display all manner of bizarre and potentially useful phenomenon
helpfulPercent: which fetch a high price in the scientific
votesHelpful: black
votesTotal: and black scientific markets.\n\nThe gameplay mechanics are a good blend of open-world scavenger hunts and solid shooter mechanics.  There are a wide variety of traditional weapons to use that often feature multiple ammo types
votesFunny: fire modes
commentsCount: and optional attachments.  One would think that with new Artifact-based tech
column16: you might find more exotic weapons as well
column17: but other than a slight exception toward the end-game
column18: you won't find any gravity guns or psy-grenades here.\n\nI say that this game is an almost-RPG simply due to the fact that
column19: despite not having attributes or XP points
column20: there is still a "grind" flow to the gameplay and a sort of character progression through acquiring gear
column21: artifacts

reviewText:
Crawling through a filthy, mutant-infested basement 20 metres below the surface of an irradiated Ukrainian wasteland, clutching a seen-better-days Kalashnikov while my Geiger counter rattles ominously, I stop to wonder why I actually enjoy S.T.A.L.K.E.R. so much.
Because, for one thing, it's hideously bleak. Playing more than an hour or so of any of the games in the series is like spending a month in Somerfield. Before long, murdering a total stranger with a hand grenade seems pragmatic rather than craven. He might have a bottle of vodka. Even the most picturesque of sunsets comes tainted with the knowledge that, shiveringly, they mostly come out at night. Mostly.
And that's where something else I don't usually really enjoy comes in: the unremitting terror. It's the noises. The skittering. The lowing. The moans. The snuffling growls which sound like an angry, adenoidal walrus mating at the bottom of a well (another familiar Somerfield experience). They're terrifying.
It's never silent in the world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.. Even during the lulls in action, which are actually much more common than the desperately-fighting-for-your-life bits, there's always the ragged wind and the caws of the wheeling crows providing a unsettling auditory rug, ready to be whisked from underneath your sense of safety by the slightest hint of a grizzle, groan or gunshot.
The sudden snarling of a pseudo-dog, barrelling from cover as I sneak across a pitch-black, anomaly-strewn bluff, is a typically pulse-thrashing moment. 20 seconds later, when the roar of my drum-fed shotgun has abated and the beast lies dead in the clinical glare of my night-vision, I've collected myself enough to rationalise the fact that it's just a dog.
A mutated, highly aggressive dog with the ability to psychically project a pack of terrifying ghost buddies, yes, but a dog nonetheless. In the Zone, this sort of thing is a minor inconvenience, but that doesn't stop me jumping out of my seat.
This tension, crafted so beautifully from the gloomy materials of the game's fractured landscape - its bestial, hypnagogic foes and the tenderly coddled supply of medicine, ammunition and equipment in your backpack - is a part of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. so intrinsic that it's become something of a one-word strapline for the series. Atmosphere.
Every dark and foreboding basement, every foetid and festering tunnel, each chattering, Learian, wind-blasted moor is pregnant with the potential for sudden and terrifying action. S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s environments seethe with sinister malevolence, despite being largely uninhabited.
The scarcity of foes - when traversing the topside environments, you'll only need your weapon once every few minutes - is completely necessary to this balance. Familiarity breeds contempt, and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.'s enemies are scattered enough to maintain their mysterious malice, just sneaky and sly enough to make your imagination teem with invisible Bloodsuckers and grim-faced Burer.
Curiously, human on human violence has been toned down considerably for the latest game, Call of Pripyat. The much-vaunted but never perfected system of factions has all but disappeared, reduced to a token discord between the hippy-go-lucky Freedom and their young Republican Duty counterparts.
Even the Bandits have calmed down enormously, chatting away to you and each other for the most part (and dependent upon your actions, of course). It's a strange choice, because often in both Clear Sky and the original Shadow of Chernobyl humans were some of the deadliest foes you would encounter.
There are still plenty of folks with radioactive chips on their shoulders, mind you, and there a few, like the fanatical space-cadet Monolith, who will attack you on sight, but generally the Zone has become an altogether more humanitarian place. If you approach a group of human enemies, even with the telltale red crosshairs and everything, they'll probably just tell you to get lost, warning you to holster your weapon well before they start shooting. Ignore their clemency and you'll soon be choking on a hot lead butty, but it's a definite change of pace.
It works, though. Clear Sky's constant re-zoning and pitched open warfare was too much too deal with and needed reining in, and Call of Pripyat has it pretty much nailed. The A-life system does all it is expected to do, and indeed all it promised as well. Mutants scuffle among themselves and with the regular patrols of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s and bandits who wander around, and dogs or Flesh can often be seen dragging bodies away. Human parties are plentiful, looting corpses and searching for artefacts in the game's large-scale anomalies.
These giant anomalies are pretty much the only place you'll find the valuable, stat-boosting artefacts, which retain their invisibility from Clear Sky and so require detectors to be found. They've evolved from the collections of smaller hazards that they were, too - becoming huge rents in the earth or giant, twisted organic structures glittering with acid or flame. Exploring them with a detector in one hand and a pistol in the other is a tense experience, simultaneously made vulnerable by lack of firepower and proximity to danger.

reviewText:
Decided to re-write this review since I don't have a limit on characters now, I don't think.

Anyway, STALKER Call of Pripyat is the 3rd game of the STALKER series and in the order of chronology, it falls in last (the first being Clear Sky, the second being Shadow of Chernobyl). STALKER is a survival semi-RPG FPS game that requires you to focus on multiple areas at once. Eating, weapon and armor management, inventory management, etc. The series is loosely based on the book Roadside Picnic by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky, although there are many differences. The act of searching for artifacts in an exclusion Zone is there, but the rest of the story is vastly different. Call of Pripyat's story, in particular, has almost nothing to do with the book. You play as USS Major Alexander Degtyarev, who is sent into the Zone following a failed mission conducted by the military to essentially map out the Zone for a full-scale military assault on the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant (CNPP). The game starts out with a cutscene that lasts maybe 5 or so minutes to give you backstory and such, and then thrusts you into the zone with bare essentials: food, bandages, first aid, and a couple guns with ammo. From there on, you're on your own. The game expects you to figure things out yourself and doesn't really outright tell you what to do. This is either exciting to you or a put off, depending on who you are. For me, it was refreshing. The first thing I did was walk up to a couple stalkers after I spawned and asked them where the nearest settlement was. They point to Skavodsk and you head there for more work. STALKER does a good job inducing a feeling of Isolation by putting you in wide open areas with very few people to be seen, except around settlements. Even then, the stalkers in these settlements will occasionally head out to gather supplies, hunt, artifact search, or just duke it out amongst themselves, so you'll find Skavodsk empty at times, aside from the merchants.
STALKER is also one of the most immersive games for me. The combination of music, ambience, and the general loneliness is so well done that it's hard to turn the game off. In Pripyat especially, there's a feeling of paranoia, as the background ambience includes whispering and quiet, soft chattering in Russian, so it always feels as if someone is nearby, and you don't know if they're friend or foe. One complaint that I have for the game is the English voice actors being really bad and making the game seem sillier than it really is. However, this can be fixed by downloading a Russian voice pack mod and english subtitle mod (I don't understand why these features weren't included to begin with but I'm glad the mods exist).
Speaking of mods, there are several mods that make the game even better. Complete, MISERY, Atmosfear and many other mods all manage to make the game more immersive, difficult, fun, beautiful and overall great. Some problems with the base game are the glitches and crashes that occur, but with some mods, some of these glitches are nonexistent, although some still remain. I highly recommend playing CoP with mods.
STALKERs mutants are also something to be addressed in themselves. There are mutants galore in the STALKER games. From the mostly docile Flesh, to the hulking Pseudo-Giant, to the mind bending Controller, every mutant is unique, and requires their own set of tactics in order to make it out in one piece.

There's so many things I'd love to talk about in STALKER. I can't possibly put them all in one review. All I can say is buy the game and find out for yourself just how well made this game was, and how much love was put into it. Here's hoping bitComposer can help get STALKER 2 off the ground, and Survarium is just as good.

reviewText:
Although it was released in 2009 , but its atmosphere is indescribable.
In it you can be in places which in 10 years will be wiped off the face of the earth because of the radiation.

Personally in my opinion this game is one of the best games from 2009 to 2012.
I don't understand people who write bad reviews for this game.
In all parts of this series turned out just fine.
I think the people who play now and who played it immediately after , will remember how they began to play, how happy they were after mnogih exciting quests and the search for artifacts.
Again in my personal opinion this game doesn't have a single minus .
Even those people who now love the game because of the graphics ,after playing it will forget that this game graphics 2009.

reviewText:
Best game in the series imo......
Clear Sky was just...ok,i think it wasn't so good and it would become really boring after a few hours ( at least it did for me ) but Shadow of Chernobyl was awesome,one of the best post-apocalyptic games out there and then there is Call of Pripyat.
i don't even know why it's so great,i mean the story is kinda meh :D the gameplay is similar to you average FPS and it doesn't have anything unique compared to other games but there is something about this game that makes it so special....it's the atmosphere,the world and how it's shown in the game.
it just feels so good to wander around and explore the world of stalker,something like Fallout ,but in a much simpler and smaller scale....

if you're planning on playing the game today make sure to install Misery 2.1 ,it's a great mod and it makes the game 10 times more appealing,not the graphics and such,it improves the entire game...

reviewText:
Welocme to the  Zone. A Post-Apocoliptic hell-on-earth. Radioactive anomalies and crazed mutant creatures. Oh yeah, and the odd bandit raid and zombie attack. Your travel agent is a ♥♥♥♥♥, unless you are Major Degretev ( I just mispelled that), a USS oprative sent in to investiagate a failed operation to the Zone. In which you discover the nature and the sheer disructive power that is the excusion zone around Chyernobl.

Gameplay 9/10. A solid method to a well filled nitch, some will find it similar to Fallout exept it is not 100% rediculus, also the artifact hunting is a cornestone of the game in its story and its economy.

Graphics 8/10. Good for a game of this type, however I don't recommend cranking the graphics to 10 unless you have a good rig.

Story 9/10. It is hard to mix story and  non-linear gameplay, but they did a good job encorpeating it.

Realism 2/10. Yes I actually made this a catagory on which I grade. This, like many other FPS games are the same. You can somehow walk out into a hail of bullets in an overcoat and somehow come out on the other side and laugh. Also if any of you have burn yourself on the oven taking something out, that is about 500 degrees F, a fire anomaly here is 1000 degrees C, and you can pitch a tent there for how long you can make it before taking  a decent amount of damage.
Another thing to know, none of the weapons in this game have their real names, ex Martha is the name for an M9.

Overall a good game which is short on realism and difficulty, which is fine. For anybody that thinks the Zone is too warm and cuddly for you, I deeply recommend the Misery mod. It is a full concept modification that changes and enhances, well every aspect of the game. As far as graphics are concerndmore contrast and darker colors, while taking the definetion up a notch or three. ( Do not attempt a high or even mid graphics if you have a low end rig). And for gameplay and realism. Well I'm not sure if you noticed, but it is called Misery for a reason. Most will spend a few hours on it and rage quit if they do it for their first playthrough, so don't. Get some COP playing on master under your belt before playing. Also, dont do what I did first time round, which is pretend you are still a tank, play this like Ghost Recon (not future soldier) avoid detection and invest in a sniper rifle. This is not for every STALKER but is worth it.

reviewText: Ukrainian and Russian post-apocalyptic open world RPG/FPS taking place around a fictional second accident at Chernobyl. This is the third and final installment in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series and features some of the smoothest gameplay of the three, and like its brethren it  has a variety of community made mods for it, namely Misery mod which is compatible with this Steam version.  A necessary addition for fans of the series, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. CoP takes place after the evens of Shadow of Chernobyl and features entirely new areas from the other two titles as well as some new enemies and phenomena.

reviewText: As someone who has played all of the Fallout games, and most of the survival-multiplayer games, I can see why they would use certain aspects of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in their ideas.\n\nGenerally, Call of Pripyat is really fun to play, even after you beat the main story. It's good for free-roam and making choices, with just enough non-linear choices to keep the player happy. It's also linear enough to keep a good story in-tact. I do say good, and not great. This game is a great game with a great feel to it, but its story cannot be described as more than good"."

reviewText:
Of the 3 games in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, this one is my favorite.  CoP is great and if you use some graphics style mods for it, the looks are quite nice for a game this age.  Least is Clear Skys though SoC (Shadow of Chernobyl) has the most diverse endings possible, it's rather cryptic to play.

Game play wise, it's wicked - you can and will get munched by things if you don't pay close attention to details.  I do like how when you hear things, like barking dogs or growls, you'll jump (almost nothing you hear is friendly").  The story is decent and the play moves at your pace with plenty of open world feel to it.

Downside:  No wait function and sleeping is only at certain times/places.  That gets annoying when you sure as hell aren't interested in going out in the dark/foggy weather in nasty areas or when you need to wait a couple game-hours for a mission.

Some modes (and there are a few) help out a bit - especially graphics style mods for visuals but I'd avoid them until you've done a playthrough first. My personal favorites are Atmosfear and Absolute Nature for looks."

reviewText:
I have just sneaked into the Waste Processing Station, which is being used by mercenaries as their camp. I have to find a notebook containing their plans and then return to Owl with the intel.

I am heavily outnumbered and outgunned. If I pick a fight with anyone, I'm dead. If I get spotted, I'm dead before I can get out the door, let alone the compound. Where is the notebook? Somewhere upstairs, I'm sure.

It's so dark I can't see anything immediately around me but the handrail of the staircase silhouetted against the fading daylight from outside. I can't risk using my flashlight. Hugging the deep shadow against the wall, I crouch and move silently. There's the notebook! Got it! Now to get out.

Can I sneak out the same way I sneaked in? I can. I pick up a jerry can of fuel as a bonus on the way out. Not a shot fired (and just as well because ammo is expensive). Who says stealth is dead? Not me! I stop to eat before starting back, just in case I need some energy to sprint for safety.

I almost make it back to the Shadovsk when I'm ambushed by a pack of mutants charging from behind. Just Flesh, so easy to handle. Mission accomplished. I'll head back to  the WPS later when I'm better armed and can hold my own against the mercs: right now I need the money that intel will get me.

No hand holding. No follow the NPC leader. No warnings of any kind of impending death. Just me and the Zone.

I had heard the S.TA.L.K.E.R. series was solid (and was already a Metro 2033 fan) so I bought Call of Pripyat on sale but then it sat there in my Steam library, neglected while I played other newer games. And then I heard about the Misery Mod. It sounded hard. It sounded scary. It looked fantastic. Misery 2.1 is cruelty ratcheted up several notches to the level of sadomasochism.

Run out of medkits? You die. Miss your headshot and don't duck back into cover fast enough? You die. Forget to pop an antiradiation pill? You watch your health slowly bleed out (and then you get into a firefight). It is just the most awesome, scary, thrilling and realistic gaming experience I've ever had.

If you want to experience a game that is as brutal as if you were in the irradiated zone around Chernobyl in real life, Misery Mod 2.1.1 is it.

UPDATE: Heading out from base, whether in Zaton, Jupiter or Pripyat, equipped and loaded for a day in the Zone of Alienation (I have now been freeplaying Misery as a Recon for hundreds of hours) not knowing whether I'm going to encounter mercs or bandits, bloodsuckers or chimeras, wondering if I'm going to locate a new stash (136+ looted so far) or just find a new ledge I can climb onto, or even acquire an unknown 23rd artifact type to add to my collection: every day in the Zone is a joy, an adrenaline rush, and a meditation on the beauty of the maps and excellent gameplay that the developers and modders created.

If I were shipwrecked on a desert island (with my PC and a power source) this would be the game I would want with me.

reviewText:
Call of Pripyat definitely lives up to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. name!
10/10 obviously.

These games have never failed to impress me. The Call of Pripyat Complete mod does volumes to improve upon the look and feel of this game, although without the mod I'd still say the game is damn near perfect like any of the other S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games. However, compared to the other games I felt like this game was... smaller... mostly because there didn't seem to be as much territory to explore. The story also seemed to be lacking a bit after playing SoC, which had an incredible story to it. They made it work though with plenty to do! I'm a huge fan of both the Fallout series and the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, and although I spend way more time on Fallout, I have to admit S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a way better RPG (if one can even consider Fallout to be an RPG).

reviewText:
Love it.

Tips for Misery noobs:

1. Always survey the area before making your move
2. Rushing in guns blazing is never a good idea
3. Conserve ammo
4. Think before you leap
5. Use grenades
6. Keep moving**
7. BATTERIES!
8. Buy things in this order in terms of priority
Equipment>Weapons>Ammo*>Armor>Mods>Food*

* - You should loot these primarily, buy only if needed
**  - The AI are Olympic grenade throwers for some reason



Despite being old, this is an overall fun and enjoyable game for survival horror and FPS fans alike although it leans towards FPS and strays from the survivor horror aspect a little bit. For first time players of this game i heavily reccomend playing on Master off the bat, seriously Easy is just a poorly balanced FPS where you swim in guns and money.

While for intermediate users who prefer a challenge, you should try the MISERY mod for S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat.
It's literally Dark Souls in Chernobyl as it takes every aspect of the game and makes it significantly harder and also adds some new elements to make it even more unforgiving, For true STALKERS only.


My Evaluation.

Pros
- Little Handholding
- Do things at your own pace
- Combat is not too easy or too hard
- Survival elements and equipment management does not feel like a chore

Cons
- English voice acting is horrible, russian vocals with english subs is better
- Money comes by too easily*
- some areas are disappointingly easy*
- Radiation is redundant and pointless*

* - Misery Mod fixes this

I have 200+ hours on this game at least, i own a CD and this on steam.
Happy hunting stalker!

reviewText:
STALKER Call of Pripyat was my first STALKER game and I can't quite say what I think of it. Overall the game was brilliant, despite being a tad bit dated I still enjoyed it nonetheless. It was exciting to start without knowing anything about it and then scavenging for artifacts through anomalies. You do quests for the people and in turn they offer you better deals or money. There's quite a bit of medicines to be used(but I never used them) and there's quite a bit of customization with the weapon and armor mods which allow you to adapt your playstyle. I was however disappointed when I reached Pripyat. The zone is very barren, not much to be done and seen. The whole thing is bugged for me, not letting me finish my game and despite having found loopholes around it, I still can't quite finish it. This one part completely ruined the game for me. The Complete Mod for it also seems to be bugged and has negative reviews. I also noticed no more artifacts spawned in anomalous areas after having left Pripyat and went to Zaton/Yanov. Overall I don't think it's worth 20€ in it's state. It's a good game, but requires fixing.

>I'd give it a 7/10(the ending completely ruined it, I'll try to fix it and update the review if possible)
>Pros: Customization, plenty of quests that affect the ending, perks/achievements, very good atmosphere, fun to discover how the game works and all it's tricks, spooky ambiance with challenging enemies.
>Cons: Graphical bugs, many other bugs which might make you unable to finish the game or quest, lack of content in the end-game, my artifacts didn't respawn after emissions nor did I have any use for most medicines in the game as all of it was trivial(running through anomalies and healing up afterwards proved to be easier)

reviewText:
Call of Pripyat is the much awaited sequel of Shadow of Chernobyl, the first STALKER game. As soon as I completed SoC I sought this game out. Needless to say it took a few hours inorder to get really into it.

The game starts out rather slow, though arguably all the STALKER games do. Once you get into the gameplay and fully immersed into the game world, you truly enjoy it. Pripyat is far more stable and less buggy then Shadow of Chernobyl was. Which is a major upside to the frequent crashing and freezing that game had. The gameplay feels a lot more streamlined with closer ties to sandbox games like Grand Theft Auto then RPGs.

Really Call of Pripyat is well worth the price of admission. It lacks the heavy plot and character presence that Shadow of Chernobyl had, but makes up for it greatly in gameplay.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A true gem. It's too bad it wasn't released on consoles (although the recoil might of been a little hard to use on a gamepad), otherwise more people would know about, and play these games, for they are truely fantastic. Great combat, where you need to actually take cover to avoid bullets, and guns are enjoyable, although enemies can sometimes feel bullet spongy, and don't really seem like they are being shot. A good open world, sadly not as large as the first two games, but they chose more specific side quests and sub-plots, although it does lack in story, because there isn't really mystery or discovery like the first two, because you know who you are, and your ultimate goal from the start. Although, I liked the ability to get awful endings because you didn't do one side quest in the ending slides, like an entire settlement being killed because you didn't do this one thing. Overall, an amazing game worth the 20$

reviewText:
After 53.5 hours of playing this game I finally finished it WITH the MISERY mod. I am in love with the STALKER series! I have not finished the two first games, Shadow of Chernobyl and Clear Sky due to annoying bugs, and of course these bugs had to happend at the end right before you go to Chernobyl NPP.... But I learned what happend there from the wiki.

In Call of Pripyat, you play as the USS Agent Alexander Degtyarev/Major Degtyarev. You have been sent to The Zone undercover to investigate why Operation Fairway failed and what happened to the crew and helicopters. On the way you will meet Stalkers, Mutants, Anomalies and Radiation. Nothing will stop you because you have the power to quicksave! Seriously... quicksave is very important in this game.

Haven't played much of the Vanilla game since it looks like ♥♥♥♥. Have tried out the Complete and MISERY mod. Never finished the story in the Complete mod but I came to the city, Pripyat. The Complete mod is for those who wants a STALKER game with less bugs and better graphics.  Misery is a very difficult mod that adds more realism and better grapichs to STALKER CoP. It's more about survival, and the start can be very tough if you have not played any STALKER games before.

I HIGHLY recommend you to play STALKER with some kind of graphical mod.

Pros and Cons

Pros

-Good gameplay
-Best atmosphere
-Scary
-Survival (Misery mod)
-Good story (play the two first games and you will understand more)
-Quicksave F5

Cons

-Bad grapichs (Vanilla)
-Annoying bugs (Vanilla and mods)

I will recommend this game for gamers who likes RPG, Survival and Action.

reviewText: The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series is one that scratches an itch that many people weren't aware they had, that of a story-based first-person shooter that doesn't skimp on the aspects of character improvement. To be fair, its narrative lacks the strength of an epic such as Half Life, but it makes up for it by presenting a plausible pseudo-scifi flair that doesn't require too much imagination to comprehend. The long and short of it is that, in the area around the Chernobyl catastrophe (known as the Zone")
date: radioactive influence has caused the birth of a number of strange anomalies
recommended: both helpful and harmful. The former come from 'artifacts'
hoursPlayed: mysterious objects possessing helpful properties like increasing the body's ability to heal
voteText: and the latter is in the form of arcane occurrences such as areas where gravity is magnified to a fatal extent
helpfulPercent: or even things as run-of-the-mill as your typical postapocalyptic creatures seeking to kill you.\n\nWhat sets the STALKER franchise apart is the emphasis on the balance between the fictional nightmares of the Zone and the interactions with other people just like you -- fortune-seekers trying to locate artifacts for their value in the world at large
votesHelpful: while avoiding the pitfalls of anomalies and mutants. While these other Stalkers may not be perfectly represented as flesh-and-blood people

column17: which would then make others view you as an enemy.\n\nCall of Pripyat is itself the latest (five years old
column18: mind you) expression of the series
column19: bringing together Shadow of Chernobyl (the first game)'s narrative coherence with Clear Sky (the second
column20: oft-panned game)'s factional warfare and open-ended nature. In CoP
column21: you find yourself in an open world
column22: with 3 main maps available to get your Stalker on. There is a centralized story to follow
column23: involving your character as a special operative for the Russian government attempting to track down the cause of the crashes of an entire squad of other operatives
column24: as if flying over the anomaly-filled Zone wasn't reason enough. But within that overall framework
column25: you are free to either maintain your military nature and focus entirely on the mission
column26: or you can go off and become a Stalker yourself
column27: searching for artifacts and misplaced caches of military gear.\n\nAs far as the story goes
column28: it's a pretty linear progression. Each map has a list of things for you to accomplish in the story's progression
column29: and at the end of those things it opens up the way to the next map. It serves a function of allowing you to explore each area
column30: without losing track of the bigger picture always lurking just beneath the surface (unlike other open-world games where you can never complete the 'main quest' and still explore the entirety of the world). This hampers the game somewhat
column32: as you as a player may feel railroaded into performing some things just for the sake of progression
column33: even if you want more time to just float around the world.\n\nThe real appeal of CoP comes from exploration. Sure
column36: just a collection of a dozen or so "points of interest"
column37: each of which corresponds to a specific scenario -- here is a building that you can explore
column38: there is a field full of Boiler anomalies that superheat the air
column39: and so forth. But in your first playthrough
column41: exploring each of these locations feels deep enough that it feels like you're really blazing new trails into the mysterious and dangerous Zone.\n\nAs far as character progression goes
column42: there aren't any RPG aspects insofar as levels and skills -- no stat distribution screens here. Instead
column43: a fluid progression system emerges from acquiring and upgrading new gear. And while there are certainly high and low ends of the spectrum for both weapons and armor
column44: an interesting upgrade system performed by a mechanic NPC means that even a beginning-of-the-game weapon can perform adequately to let you handle the toughest of mutants and the most heavily-armed NPCs. The real limiting factor is money -- but
column45: as you get more money and/or loot to sell as you do more things in the world
column46: it functions as a sort of experience system
column47: where getting enough money lets you buy a new suit of armor
column48: or perhaps a few upgrades to the suit you already have that increases its survivability in radioactive environments.\n\nMoving on to artifacts: As explained earlier
column49: artifacts are mysterious (there's that word again) objects possessing unique abilities that
column51: are helpful to your character. This comes at a cost
column53: as many artifacts are still inherently radioactive (represented by a +# representation
column55: and will cause you harm if you use them for too long. Their use is through their placement in an "artifact pouch"
column56: wherein their effects -- both positive and negative -- will be able to affect you. Or you can always just carry them in your backpack
column58: but can't help you either. And thus a balance has to be struck between using artifacts that help you in the near future -- mental protection as you're about to fight telepathic mutants
column59: for example -- and either bearing the radioactivity
column60: using your precious anti-rad meds as a stopgap measure
column61: or using one of the slightly-rarer anti-radioactivity artifacts (which have -# in the radioactivity measurement)
column62: the lattermost of which can negate the other artifacts
column63: and even give you a baseline radioactivity resistance.\n\nWith that
column64: I come to the final point
column65: which is the plethora of in-game stats that the player has to take into effect. There are eight
column66: each with their own means of being inflicted and being protected against or healed. Roughly speaking
column67: these stats and a brief summary are:\n\n1.) Impact -- The effect (damage and flinching) of gravitational effects (anomalies or stuff being thrown at you telekinetically)
column68: or being smacked around by mutants with physical attacks\n2.) Wounding/Bleeding -- Slow health loss through cuts

3.) Explosion -- Self-explanatory

5.) Burn -- The damage of thermal effects (fires

etc.)
6.) Chemical -- The damage of chemical hazards (typically anomalies)
7.) Electric -- The damage of electrical anomalies
8.) Radiation -- The damage and effect (screen blurring

etc.) of radioactive objects and anomalies
9.) Psy/Mental -- The damage and effect of mental attacks (almost exclusively by psychic mutants)

As you can see
column75: there are many stats to be concerned with
column76: but they fall into two general categories -- combat and environment. For the most part
column77: environmental resistances are only momentary concerns based on the current situation -- no need to worry about Burn resistance unless you're going into a field of hot anomalies -- wheareas the combat stats are all-round necessities. The trick is to balance finding armor with the stats you need (with upgrades providing some measure of balance for stats they lack)
column78: artifacts that will resist what you're about to do in the immediate future
column79: and using on-demand items that temporarily boost resistances.\n\nIn the end
column80: the Zone is worth at least one solid playthrough
column81: even if in doing so you explore every point of interest
column83: and collect every piece of gear possible. An emergent mod community has also put together mods doing everything from merely adding a handful of gear to be found
column84: to some introducing entire new zones imported from the previous games. In the end
column85: I would conclude that S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is worth playing
column86: if for no other reason than to demonstrate that an FPS can have a non-setpiece story
column88: without losing part of itself in the process."

reviewText:
The most polished STALKER game, and unfortunately, probably the last.

COP takes the best parts of SOC and Clear Sky and blends them into one game. The storyline features some rpg-esque choices and consequences, many side quests/faction content and a highly improved weapon/suit upgrade system (first introduced in Clear Sky).

Graphically, the game's textures and models look quite outdated, but the game makes up for it with superb use of DX11 lighting and shaders. There are also many graphical mods available to improve the quality of the models and textures. On the subject of mods, the game still has a thriving mod community that makes everything from gameplay overhauls to total conversions.

Whether you've played the previous STALKER games, or are a fan of RPG/FPS hybrids (or just FPS/RPGs), COP is well worth your time.

reviewText:
As a technical note, I've played this game until its final culminating 10 minutes, because the game just doesn't manage to keep itself running when I reach a certain point in the final evacuation, about halfway through the mission. After seeing videos about the final minutes, I haven't missed too much.

So, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.. Perhaps my favorite game series of all time. In many ways a review of this final installment of the series is a commentary on them all. Excluding obvious technical remarks about poor optimization, poor stability at times and glitches ranging from hilarious to potentially game-breaking, I have mostly praise to deliver.

Stalker-games all center around on adventuring - and at times, merely surviving - in what possibly is the most wonderful theme that has ever blessed mankind, which at the same time is one of the most horrific disasters striking that said mankind. Stalker-games' relation to the accident at Chernobyl is tangential at best (the same could be said about its relation to the Roadside Picnic novel and Stalker movie), it still captures enough of the real to make for compelling fantasy. Reality does not stop at the theme itself, but the fact that much of the speech and non-spoken text is also preserved in its original form of Russian (even though it should probably be Ukrainian, but what do we stupid self-centered westerners know?) makes the game feel so much more genuine than your run-of-the-mill modern shooter, where the most foreign element you encounter is heavily accented English.

Even though Stalkers do not aim to be ARMA-like simulators, they nonetheless take certain pride in their genre. Iron sights are viable, even mandatory, and different weapons and alternative ammunition are plenty, if somewhat dumbed-down in this third installment, compared to the first game. Armor and weapons can be upgraded with numerous convincing-sounding doodads which, while not always presenting itself too clearly what their actual benefit to the player is, serves as an addictive middle-term goal. With some differences I would say all Stalker-games can be discussed as a one entity. Even though balance changes between each game, and the first game being possibly mechanically most poor, if you like one Stalker-game, you probably at least tolerate them all.

To say something about Call of Pripyat itself, while being immensely recommendable to all shooter game fans, it still falls short compared to what I see as the Ultimate Stalker, Shadow of Chernobyl. While it does quite well exploring its own side of the universe, it still manages to deliver the story as more simple, much less mystical and intriguing as the first two games did. It feels too much like an epilogue, which it irreversably is. Possibly this is partially planned. Without going into too much (spoiler-)detail, to the player the Zone no longer bears any mysticism. You have already learned its secrets, already know what makes it tick. You no longer even play a lone wanderer intent on deciphering its secrets, you are a government man on a mission that only accidentally happens to uncover more of the truth. And even in this it manages to do so in almost sorrowful frontier fiction -fashion: now that mystery is solved, control can be established and the myth has to make room for reality. What was already a world of the past ceases to exist altogether. In a considerably concrete way the game punts you out to the post-Stalker world. The Old can be revisited, but never again experienced in the same way. Or that is how I, with a touch of melodrama, understand it.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.-games offer a quite unique and compelling setting in an enjoyable, if unpolished way. Their genuine delivery feels exceptionally loving treatment of an IP, at least comparing to many modern shooters, or games in general. If one requires alleviation to Stalker-withdrawal, Metro-series is a worthy runner-up, if not a perfect match. 5/5 x 3.

reviewText: This is an excellent game that doesn't get much attention, unfortunatelly. The atmosphere of it is excellent and so is the gameplay. It flaws only at the cheesy cutscene dialogues. Also, after beating this game once I deffinitely reccomend that you get a mod for it called MISERY. It brings an enormous realism to the game and makes the Zone the true nightmare that it was meant to be. Having to fend off 4 bandits (which now attack you on sight) with a corroded Makarov and only a few rounds is not for the weak. Take the Dark Road Beggining if you want to be a true STALKER. MISERY is regarded as one of the most difficult mods of all times. Somehow, you'll also get addicted to some russian music, even thought you can't understand a word of what they are saying.

- No new sequal yet
- Dated Graphics (Minor)
8.75/10
Recommended to Fallout fans and people who like that atmospheric feeling.
We need more of these kind of games.

reviewText:
Last of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, still the best
As you play troughout in the Zone you will feel that creepy atmosphere, because you never know where friends are camping, or an bloodsucker is lurking.
Weapon, armor and helmet upgrade and repairsystem is the best of all, weapons have realistic damage, AP ammo is really good agains armor, as it should be at any game.
Enemy AI is really advanced since the Clear sky, for example: Bloodsuckers now dont approach you when cloacked, as they try to flank you and get their tentacles around your neck and suck your blood from your body.
Stash system is good too, as you need medkits, ammo, armor, weapons, helmets and drugs troughout the game.
The only thing matters me in this game, that you cant make own stashes, but that will be fixed in the Misery 2.0 mod.
Buy this game if you like scary survival with mysterious missions.
PS: the emissions are really something, as you try to run to cover you have to move fast, if enemy is infront of you you just have to run for your life, or the Zone takes your life.
