reviewText:
Awesome game, retains a suspenseful tone and a strong horror vibe, stepping up enemies with the player; it's a great game and I highly recommend. It's a challenge, it's well-done, it's based on a book...
This game pretty much has it all... with the exception of the Steam overlay.

But, 'Slow down, chief! Put that shooter away first...'

When you suit up in an exoskeleton with night vision and a full-auto shotgun to stomp out a group of bandits who swindled you ten minutes ago, when you push home the final of 3 rpg rounds you've saved the whole game to blow up the Pseudogiant in the next room, when you use all your food and medkits, but just manage to survive that Emission with cover still a mile away, when you turn Beard down and keep that Bubble artifact... when you feel the Call of Pripyat at last and with iron resolve trek through the Jupiter Plant's long-sealed catacombs...

... You will love this game with all your heart and soul.






Why are you still reading this? GET OUT OF HERE, STALKER!

reviewText: Unbelievably much much better than the predecessors, this is like the STALKER game you always wanted. It has this certain 'final touch' that all the others lacked and so you'd constantly get stuck or screw yourself over, this one is more easy and smoothly to play, while it also has the very immersive and realistic landscape of Tchernobyl, with better implemented enemies such as even creepier mutants, zombies and the works that was missing before.. At times I was too scared to go on, and coming from me, that says something. It should be noted that it is also extremely crash-happy still, so make sure to save often. It really encourages exploration and actually leaves it up to the player to how much time they really want to invest in it, and it rewards that. Very neat design.

reviewText:
If survival FPS is what you are looking for then look no further. I started the series with Shadow of Chernobyl, which I highly recommend to play first. Even though the two stories arent strictly linked, the game and atmosphere feels alot more developed once you play through SoC.

If you decide to jump into Call of Pripyat anyways then once you get past the steep learning curve youll find yourself in a pretty large world without much indication of what to do. Basically all you need to know is that everything is out to kill you and unless youre 10+ hours into the game, everything will kill you without even giving you a chance. Hitting that F5 button is a must every 2 minutes because you can and you will die every 2 minutes in your first playthrough. Getting money to buy better gear is a must and doing the side missions just happen as you go along. Once you find yourself being able to kill bandits and small fry mutants, then you are in a position to actually start the main story and continue the game as intended.

Pros of this game is that the atmosphere in this is unmatched by any game ive played since its release up to the time of this review. The gun physics is amazing as the bullets are physical objects and shooting just doesnt get any more satisfying than this, that I can garuantee. The survival elements of this game are really harsh at first but once you get mid range equipment, you should be able to get a reasonable income for items and such to keep you going. End game is mainly about exploring and the survival elements are very minimal as youre probably pretty rich by then and the stores always have enough supply.

Cons are that even though the game is open world with alot of varying activities, I have to say that to me the main story felt no different than doing a very long series of side missions. Theres also the fact that once you reach a certain point in the game, the atmosphere changes from survival to just completing missions and loses alot of its immersion (IMO).

On the plus side again though there is a HUGE amount of mods available for this game and trying them out gives you a new experience every time.

reviewText:
Previous games : STALKER Chernobyl and Clear Sky.
I played both many many years ago.

Game style : slow pace shooter meets RPG in open world environment
*A little bit of RPG.....,talk to persons, encumberance, buy and sell goods, upgrade your weapons and armor,
tweak your characteristics with artefacts, get missions by approaching NPCs
*Shooter : pistol, shot gun, sniper, grenades, rocket launcher, take cover, aim for the head
*Slow pace : most of the time you will spend on moving from one place to another

Difficulty : played on Veteran which is recommendable as long as you take cover.

Story line : Although the universe you are in is derived from a book serie, the story line of the game is poor and paper thin, like shooters mostly do.
Dialogues : Short and necessary to pick up missions. Missions are not always that clear.

Combat system (8/10) :
shoot, throw, stab and hide in cover.
bleed, use bandage or use artifact
loose healing points, use med kit or artifact

Atmosphere (9/10):
unique setting, always the feeling of being in danger, playing during night time brings on the most joy / thrill

Graphics (8/10) :
ok, game is 7 yrs old but looks still fine to me. I played Crysis 3 just before this one
and was not shocked (even when standing in an electricity anomaly).
Played Pripyat on the highest settings

Music (10/10) :
It's atmospheric and blends very well during gaming, not to mention the additional sound of lightening,
barking dogs, howling wolfs, crows, mourning zombies.

Difficulty :
play at least on veteran level, difficulty can always be changed during course of the game,

Bugs :
this version is bug free

Hello, anyone there ? : Two places, the Jupiter factory and the zone Pripyat are underdeveloped.
It's just me, myself and I.

To play or not to play :
If you played Chernobyl and Clear sky before, it will feel more of the same
If you never played STALKER, go for it if you do not mind that pace is slow
I hope to see a STALKER 3 in near future and some more budget to get it on a higher level.

PC gamer, started gaming in the 80's with arcade hall games (galaxy, pac-man, gum shoe),
Atari console (River Raid,...), Commodore 64 (Decathlon, Commando,...), Amiga 500 and finally PC (Myst, 7th Guest, Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, C&C....) and clock is still ticking :=P

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat is the third, and with GSC Game World closing down, most likely the last game in the stalker series. The stalker games were a surprise hit right from the start and it's a shame to see the series end, especially with this game where everything seems to turning in the right direction once again.\n\nCall of Pripyat, like the other stalker games, is an open world first person shooter with some minor RPG elements thrown in for good measure. You roam the radioactive wasteland surrounded Chernobyl, searching for artifacts"
date: valuable and rare commodities created by the various spacial anomalies created by the nuclear meltdown so many years ago. To keep things interesting you will have to contend with other stalkers wanting the artifacts for themselves
recommended: shadowy organizations with their own secret agendas
hoursPlayed: the Ukrainian military and of course
voteText: horribly mutated monsters.\n\nOne thing that Call of Pripyat does notably different from it's predecessors is slowing things down quite a bit. Instead of every map being a battlefield of constant and relentless attacks by seemingly unending forces from the various factions populating the zone combat is now much rarer. This has the very welcoming effect of making the game world feel like the radioactive wasteland it's supposed to be
helpfulPercent: every encounter is more intense because of it and it feels a little special when you encounter a group of stalkers who promptly tell you to holster your weapons or get lost rather than simply open fire on sight.\n\nThe faction system that was present in Clear Sky has all but been removed and this also helps push the pace of the game more towards Survival Horror than Mindless Shooter. While the factions still exists
votesHelpful: still do battle with one another and still treat you differently depending on your actions there is no constant defend and attack missions and broken faction relations and this goes a long way towards making you feel like you're playing your own game
votesTotal:
rather than just being another soldier in a never ending war.

Despite all the good there is still plenty of bad however. The game is much smaller than both it's predecessors and the great storyline and mysteries from Shadow of Chernobyl is nowhere to be found. Also the difficulty has been toned down considerably which will elate some and irate others.

The engine is still pretty bad
votesFunny: the animations have been cleaned up a little but are still very clunky and despite the graphical enchantments that the series has been undergoing since Clear Sky this game still has that "raw" feeling of Shadow of Chernobyl. That feel like you're playing something half-done. Something that could have used another year of polishing. While this might normally be enough to make you quit the game Call of Pripyat manages to accomplish the same fear as the original. It makes you enjoy it despite it's many flaws. Sure you will probably grab the first graphical enhancement mod you come across but that's not because you can't play the game without it
commentsCount: it's because you have to play the game regardless and just want to spare your eyes a little.\n\nCall of Pripyat is a good way to end the stalker series I suppose. It's a good game and has many improvements over it's predecessors. But completing I still feel like something is lacking. A true "S.T.A.L.K.E.R 2" might not be something we will ever see but it sure is something we can hope for."

reviewText: The most polished game of the trilogy, STALKER COP follows the story of Shadow of Chernobyl, its a free roam FPS with RPG elements like looting, buying & upgrading weapons, sleeping, etc. Just like SoC, it provides a unique atmosphere of complete desolation & loneliness, mixed with a hostile enviroment full of mutated creatures, zombiefied humans, factions that collide with eachother & lots of natural hazard like emissions that force you to take shelter, radioactive areas, dangerous anomalies, etc. Its a unique experience, you'll love it or hate it. If you're tired of hollywood-like games and you're looking for something more underground, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
This was the most enjoyable FPS I have ever played. After trying out various mods for this game, I eventually went with Misery Mod 1.0 (2.0 was too much for my wimpy laptop, but I personally think 1.0 was better anyway). I also completed the game on Master difficulty.

Modding aside, CoP is a brilliant open-world shooter. While there is a story that the player eventually needs to progress through, the open-world element puts you in control of the pace of the game so you can explore/merc all you want and then perform the essential plotline tasks when you're ready. I loved the idea of three gigantic levels taking the places of seven or eight smaller ones. The gunfights are technical and challenging. The finale of this game is terrific - probably the most intense gunfight I've experienced in a game.

By the time I was done with CoP's prequels, I was craving more difficulty, so I installed Misery, which was pretty unforgiving in the early game. It also creates a bleak atmosphere, adds new weapons, and changes the sound a bit. The mod also tweaked the random events, keeping the player on edge. I HIGHLY recommend this game with the Misery mod.

reviewText:
Great open-world game. If you like Fallout 3, then consider the STALKER series Fallout on steroids. Combat is intense, against both humans and mutants alike, and a single headshot from an enemy is enough to take you out. You have an absurd amount of freedom in this game. If you want to shoot the guy giving you a mission, you can. If you want to shoot the guy who just rewarded you for completing a mission, you can. I've already been playing this game, CoP for about 15 hours and haven't even started with the mainline story missions, there's so much else you can do.

Not to mention this game is so DYNAMIC. Enemies get into firefights if they're in opposing groups, or mutants against humans. Bandits and other stalkers will loot dead bodies after killing them. Wounded enemies can either be healed with one of your medkits or executed. Wild packs of mutants will kill human AI and drag their bodies off to be eaten. And anomolies don't discriminate against who they destroy. These are things that were in all of the STALKER games, mind you.

If you do decide to get this game, be sure to download either the complete (better graphics, improved gameplay, bug fixes) or the Misery (same as Complete only a LOT harder) mods. They're a good pick for even a first time run through, though I would only do Misery if you are really patient and don't mind dying a lot.

reviewText:
This was the most enjoyable FPS I have ever played. After trying out various mods for this game, I eventually went with Misery Mod 1.0 (2.0 was too much for my wimpy laptop, but I personally think 1.0 was better anyway). I also completed the game on Master difficulty.

Modding aside, CoP is a brilliant open-world shooter. While there is a story that the player eventually needs to progress through, the open-world element puts you in control of the pace of the game so you can explore/merc all you want and then perform the essential plotline tasks when you're ready. I loved the idea of three gigantic levels taking the places of seven or eight smaller ones. The gunfights are technical and challenging. The finale of this game is terrific - probably the most intense gunfight I've experienced in a game.

By the time I was done with CoP's prequels, I was craving more difficulty, so I installed Misery, which was pretty unforgiving in the early game. It also creates a bleak atmosphere, adds new weapons, and changes the sound a bit. The mod also tweaked the random events, keeping the player on edge. I HIGHLY recommend this game with the Misery mod.

reviewText:
Call of Pripyat is what Clear Sky should have been. Here, the game finally offers a completely new map with new places to visit and NPCs to interact with. Also, it continues the story of the first Stalker game. You, as a stalker and agent, investigate why several helicopters crashed during their mission which aimed to scout the area so that the military could find out how exactly the Zone had changed after the events of the first game.

This seems to be the most stable of all the Stalker games and it should also be noted that the only one offering you to stay once the main story is completed. It was annoying in the previous two games that I was not exactly notified that once the journey to the centre of the Zone started all my side missions would remain incomplete. Here, at the end of the game, you can make a decision to stay and complete any unfinished quests you had or explore any undiscovered areas.

Also, this Stalker game seems to be the only one that rarely had any crashes when I was playing it - it is a stable version where you encounter few glitches or bugs. This is of course all the feedback on the vanilla game as the COMPLETE mod was also released for this version further enhancing the Stalker experience. Still, it is commendable that GSC Game World put enough time and effort to release a functional game that was enjoyable without having to wait for further patches on the date of release.

Call of Pripyat should be picked up by those who liked Shadow of Chernobyl. Do skip Clear Sky and pick this one in its stead. After installing the game install the COMPLETE mod to have the best Stalker experience to date.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game, as well as it's predecessors, is one of the best games I have EVER played. While there are some bugs and the graphics, as well as animations for the characters, are a bit derpy the games story still shines through. In my humble opinion, if you like post-apocalyptic first person shooters with an Open-World and RPG elements, then you will absolutely adore this game! And if you love a game with a good story then you should play the entire S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series because it will most likely blow you away. It's a damn fine game and I'd recommend it to almost everyone!

reviewText: The STALKER series has terrified me for a very long time and Call of Pripyat is, in my eyes at least, the best of the three. Blending a terrifying open world with survivalist gameplay to create in the player, unbridled horror. The supernatural elements are terrific, the gunplay is visceral, and the twisted abominations (and the bloody Poltergeists) will make you jump.\n\nIt also has a terrific modding community which I would implore any player to explore. I can't recommend this game, and the series, enough.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I keep getting drawn back to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series for some reason. There's a certain charm to its depressing, post-apocalyptic countryside.\n\nThe gunplay is fun and the atmosphere is brilliantly terrifying. Vanilla is pretty good (albeit a bit rough around the edges) however it's best played with overhaul mods, of which there are a lot to choose from. I've played the previous two games a little bit but out of the three, Call of Pripyat is the one I have enjoyed the most.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a game of survival in a nuclear waste ridden land filled with mutants, and men who would like nothing more than to steal your artifacts and leave you stranded to die. If they didn't kill you first. The game has a great post-apocalyptic setting, and a serious knack for bringing you into situations you don't know if you get out of alive.\n\nIf you do pick this game up and enjoy it very much I would suggest downloading the Misery 2.0 mod. It adds new mechanics as well as a much more cut throat difficulty to the game.

reviewText: An awe inspiring experience. The atmosphere and open world enviroment are so immersive, you'll forget it's a game. The firefights are moderately paced, tactical engagements where things such as manpower, stealth, weather, and other little factors play just as much of a role as pointing and shooting. While the story is a solid continuation from SoC, it suffers greatly from very poor english voice-overs, some spotty writing and liberal use of Deus Ex Machinas in side quests and the main story. Overall, this game is a treat. It may not be as flashy as the equally stellar (but more linear) metro series, but if you wanna know where metro took it's inspiration, pick this one up. The great modding community have extended the life of this game very well since it's 2010 release, so definitely check ModDB if you find the time.

reviewText: I was introduced to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series with Call of Pripyat and then later went back and played the first and second games. I found that the Call of Pripyat and it's in game mechanics are so addictive and there is so much replay value that I can't even tell you what playthrough number I'm up to now. A fantastic game that only gets better with mods. I admit that the game is rough around the edges, a number of bugs here and there and odd errors that can come up every now and then but if you have a mild to wild system you shouldn't have any dramas. I strongly suggest the Arsenal Overhaul mod, paired with Atmosfear and Absolute Nature. This game I always end up coming back to, when I dont know what else to play, I end up playing this, the only game worthy of a Desktop Shortcut on my PC. 10/10

reviewText: Call of Pripyat is a mixed bag. It incorporates the gameplay and graphical improvements of Clear Sky and introduces new and large areas to explore. It's also the most polished and bug-free of the STALKER games. But at the same time it seems to have lost its spirit: the game is very unchallenging and the Zone doesn't feel like the oppressive and bleak place it should be anymore.\nDespite its shortcomings Call of Pripyat is recommendable simply because it works. It has a lot of content in both items and quests, it's very free-roam right from the start and it's overall the most accessible of the three games.

reviewText:
Before reading this review make sure you’ve read my reviews of the previous games:

Shadow of Chernobyl http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/4500/

Clear sky http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197984765152/recommended/20510/

(And just like with the previous games, I played this on the highest difficulty and WITHOUT MODS, don’t spend your time complaining about that)

Call of Pripyat is the last game in the series which happens a few years after Shadow of Chernobyl.
You play as Major  Alexander Degtyarev, who is sent in to investigate the failure of this operation which the reasons why are extremely anti-climactic and the ending leaves you somewhat disappointed, in fact the story in this game is made to quite existent but it just ends up falling flat on its face onto a turd.

Call of Pripyat does add in a few new things: on the map areas are now highlighted with a bubble, the hunger system was brought back and emissions happen on a somewhat regular basis and you must take shelter and wait for them to be over. Call of Pripyat also improves a few things as well: now the gunplay is so much better than before, weapons jam a lot less than clear sky, and it only takes one bandage or med kit to stop you from bleeding out when clear sky it took a random amount of healing items.

Just like the previous games this is a strangely compelling game but it still comes with a few issues:

Everything weighs more in this game and you’ll be over the weight limit quite a lot in this game so you’ll be walking everywhere instead of running, when in the previous games you could carry two assault rifles, one sub machinegun, one handgun, one shotgun and a stack of ammo and healing items, when in Call of Pripyat I was over the limit on just having two assault rifles, one handgun, and a stack of ammo and healing items.

With gunfights it’s still very random on whether the enemies will hit you or not and how much damage they dish out to you.

And lastly this game does get quite boring at times since to begin with the mission objectives are really, really boring, since it’s usually go here examine object, and that the landscape is very baron and there’s quite a lack of enemies around.

This is a fairly good game and getting this comes down to whether you can be patient with it otherwise you’ll probably be too bored to play it.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: An awe inspiring experience. The atmosphere and open world enviroment are so immersive, you'll forget it's a game. The firefights are moderately paced, tactical engagements where things such as manpower, stealth, weather, and other little factors play just as much of a role as pointing and shooting. While the story is a solid continuation from SoC, it suffers greatly from very poor english voice-overs, some spotty writing and liberal use of Deus Ex Machinas in side quests and the main story. Overall, this game is a treat. It may not be as flashy as the equally stellar (but more linear) metro series, but if you wanna know where metro took it's inspiration, pick this one up. The great modding community have extended the life of this game very well since it's 2010 release, so definitely check ModDB if you find the time.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I was introduced to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series with Call of Pripyat and then later went back and played the first and second games. I found that the Call of Pripyat and it's in game mechanics are so addictive and there is so much replay value that I can't even tell you what playthrough number I'm up to now. A fantastic game that only gets better with mods. I admit that the game is rough around the edges, a number of bugs here and there and odd errors that can come up every now and then but if you have a mild to wild system you shouldn't have any dramas. I strongly suggest the Arsenal Overhaul mod, paired with Atmosfear and Absolute Nature. This game I always end up coming back to, when I dont know what else to play, I end up playing this, the only game worthy of a Desktop Shortcut on my PC. 10/10

reviewText: I keep getting drawn back to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series for some reason. There's a certain charm to its depressing, post-apocalyptic countryside.\n\nThe gunplay is fun and the atmosphere is brilliantly terrifying. Vanilla is pretty good (albeit a bit rough around the edges) however it's best played with overhaul mods, of which there are a lot to choose from. I've played the previous two games a little bit but out of the three, Call of Pripyat is the one I have enjoyed the most.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a game of survival in a nuclear waste ridden land filled with mutants, and men who would like nothing more than to steal your artifacts and leave you stranded to die. If they didn't kill you first. The game has a great post-apocalyptic setting, and a serious knack for bringing you into situations you don't know if you get out of alive.\n\nIf you do pick this game up and enjoy it very much I would suggest downloading the Misery 2.0 mod. It adds new mechanics as well as a much more cut throat difficulty to the game.

reviewText: This game is a great survival FPS. Good mechanics, a nice range of weapons easily modifiable, and good difficulty that isn't too excessive. That's the short. Now for the long.\n\nThe long is that S.T.AL.K.E.R. is a great survival FPS renown for it's excellent portrayal of The Zone, a post-Chernobyl irradiated anomaly in Ukraine that is growing day by day expanding it's influence and luring treasure hunters guns-for-hire and thieves all to it's landscape for either massive wealth or their inevitable doom. Some of you might think, but Wille
date: this has been done before. Why is this any different?" It isn't but it's done right and that's the key difference. A lot of survival games might thrust you into an area you know all of nothing about. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. doesn't do this. Your character is given plenty of dialogue with other characters as they slowly establish this large world around you from the starting area outwards. It's done like this in all of the series' titles and that is easily their best feature. Where they don't excel in graphics they do excel in amazing story and worldbuilding among other things
recommended: and the graphics are more than passable.\n\nOn to gunplay and mechanics. It's a survival game so you have your standard fare here. Heavy-hitting high recoil weapons that shred mooks and shred you if you're naked along with the typical things like hunger
hoursPlayed:
radiation and the ability to bleed. Bleeding is easily stopped with twenty plasters applied on the wound whether it's a shot from a 9 mil or a crater-making blast from an anti-materiel rifle. This works to the game's benefit as it is a survival game but it also doesn't have to be overly difficult to be one. Many survival games think survival is ball-busting fun-stifling monsters teabagging your corpse death after death before you can even reach the level one safe zone. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has always given you time to prepare where other games wouldn't. For this reason alone it could get my reccomendation it could look Minecraft bad and with mechanics like this I'd still love it over anything any day of the week.

Not much more can be said. The flaws could be focused on but there aren't many. Buy the game and play it.

-  Excellent world spanning 3 games
-  Satisfying gunplay that rewards patience and skill

reviewText: The STALKER series has terrified me for a very long time and Call of Pripyat is, in my eyes at least, the best of the three. Blending a terrifying open world with survivalist gameplay to create in the player, unbridled horror. The supernatural elements are terrific, the gunplay is visceral, and the twisted abominations (and the bloody Poltergeists) will make you jump.\n\nIt also has a terrific modding community which I would implore any player to explore. I can't recommend this game, and the series, enough.

reviewText:
I was kinda disappointed, even though they added some new great things, it had me longing for the oringanal SoC game play. I don't think some things were 100% finnished, and it seems to really need mods to help the game play, which isn't good or bad but for me, personally, but I had a hard time getting the right mods together.

In vinilla gameplay, the first things I realized were wrong were the ak-74u and the gun sounds. They were waaay to quite, kinda unsatisfyng, Thankfully theres a mod for that that isn't so hard to find. The ak-74u on the other hand just looked wierd, the ejection port was on the left side; I had to watch poorly renderd casings come out the wrong side of the gun. A.I., of course, is also bad. It needed mods.

Once I got to modding I saw a lot of great mods, or from the cover they look good. A lot of recent bad reviews kept me from the bigger mods (misery, complete, ect.) so I looked for mods with good reviews. the SGM mods (both 2.2 and geo) were o.k. but still not the expirince I was looking for, So then I tried the a couple of mod packs. Some had this others had that, none were good enough. Now, I finnialy tried misery 2.0 and it was actully really good.

Over all, I give it a 8.5/10 after getting misery, amazing realistic, horrer survival game play.
Then I got the killer mod pack" now it's like a 9.5/10

reviewText: A worthy successor. It keeps everything that mad SoC good but adds a more expansive and living world. It's very well done. There's not much more to be said that I haven't said in my review of SoC. A word of advice to you modders though; before playing the Misery mod (the mod that makes this game more difficult than running through Dark Souls using the broken sword) I'd suggest properly preparing yourself for iminent death. I was torn apart by Pseudodogs within 30 seconds of starting the mod. If you enjoy challenge, immersion, and the previous STALKER games you'll love this one....... and if you enjoy an insane amount of difficulty you should download the Misery mod.

reviewText: Although this is my first and only S.T.A.L.K.E.R game I can see how it definitely is in a league of its own. I am a really huge fan of horror games, first person shooters, and open world, and this game puts all of those together beautifully and in such a unique way. Also if you like to push yourself in video games this game is definitely the Dark Souls of FPS and I feel the best way to immerse yourself in this game is to play it on master and if you find it too difficult then that's too bad because that is the life of a S.T.A.L.K.E.R.(plus there's the Misery Mod). Plus I can't count how many times I've been killed by one shot on master difficulty, or how many times I have to repair armor/guns. Also its also the little things in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. world that can be the most meomorable. I would wonder through the world and stumble upon four other S.T.A.L.K.E.R's playing music and drinking vodka with dead animal carcasses everywhere, and I would be talking to a bandit and a dog mauled him during conversation and his bandit buddies would walk away (because freinds stick up for one another right?). I haven't come close to finishing it as I just got to Pripyat in the game, but I can also tell you that the sidequests aren't too repetitive, unoriginal, and boring. The only problems I have so far are the stiff characters and the english voice acting of the AI, but again, there's a mod that has the AI speak russian if you want it to be realistic. The graphics aren't mind blowing (but they are really good none the less and it's always worth killing yourself to watch an emission take place), but if you play for the graphics than you are not welcome here. Once I'm able to finish the game I can talk about the story.

reviewText:
On one hand along with ShoC, these two games are one of the best I've ever played.  On the other, the developers are long since fired and have gone on to new studios, new games and won't see a dime of your money.

The story behind the game is sadly wrapped in greed, bad treatment, and corruption.  Which is probably why the story IN the game richly portrays those things.

While it's one of my favorite games and the second best of the series (ShoC > CoP > CS), I'd recommend you get it for as cheap as possible.

Also it's aged like vinegar unfortunately.  It was ahead of its time when ShoC came out with advanced A-Life AI that lived and breathed in the world instead of sitting waiting for you to show up and interact with it.  But by the time CoP was released it was already aging and it's been a long time since this game released.

All three games have wonderful modding communities that add replayability to it and are still active even after all this time.

reviewText:
Absolutely amazing game with a superb atmosphere and interesting locations, people, and storylines.

Pros:
-Great atmosphere and doesn't overdo the horror element, but the intended parts *are* truly scary.

-Unique locations, while some locations are underused, there is a wide variety of different things to look at and experience.

-Interesting backstory that captures a lot of mystery. While the main plot is good itself, a lot of the best moments come from the side quests.

-Enemies are well done. There is a decent range of different mutants with different focuses.

-Alive world. Unlike something like skyrim where 99% of the encounters are scripted, the game's entire world has different squads and mutants shifting about. Since practically no NPCs are unkillable, this can lead to some people you have invested a bit of time into being killed while on patrol.

-Better ending(s) than Mass Effect 3. While this game doesn't have a lot of traditional RPG elements, the branching endings make a lot of the questlines more meaningful.

Cons:
-The world isn't that big. Okay, this is probably a more extreme version of what I experienced with skyrim. After the 500th hour or whatever, you know the landscape to an extent to where the game world can't offer anything new. But yeah, the way the world is split up into three areas really limits the spaces you can visit without a guide. The earlier games handled this much better with smaller maps, but a seemingly larger space in total. Now, of course, this game does pretty much everything else better.

-Bugs. It really doesn't seem that bad, but they do occur and I pretty much unconciously ignore them since I'm used to that type of thing. I would still consider it less buggy than Skyrim. I haven't ever had any quests break entirely, but I have had to reload my last save a few times.

-AI. On any mission where you have to follow/lead around any AI, its failures become readily apparent. Due to some of the unreasonably strict casualty limitations to get some of the better ending slides, this can either require some save-scumming or just dealing with the worse ending. But seriously, the AI is extremely sucky against mutants and grenades. They feel like CoD level NPCs where they aren't even trying to fight properly against the enemy.

Anyway, the Complete" mod would be worthwhile for a second playthrough (or a first if you are particularily pedantic). It nice-inates the graphics while staying mostly true to the game. reviewText:
Probably the best game in the series due to many improvements and bugs fixed. The game is amazing and the developers sure put their best into it and hopefully they can release another S.T.A.L.K.E.R game in the near future.

Here are some pro's and con's

PROS:
+The new eye candy such as DX11 and Tessellation
+Advanced 10.1 support
+New level of textures/lighting
+Fantastic sense of place
+Lots of tense exploration
+Numerous improvements over the previous games
+Some cool new enemies to take on
+Still charming despite it's flaws
+Great NPC interactions
+Better side jobs

CONS:
-Some recycled props, but no where near as many as Clear Sky
-Ever present Xray stutter" is still here when entering a spawn area for the first time
-Still taxing on older systems despite the leaps forward in stability and polish
-The story takes too long to get interesting
-Pripyat isn't as interesting as the surrounding wastes
-Eating mechanic is tedious
-Supplies are too available
-Predictable encounters

Depiste some stuff still being recycled from the older games its still pretty great. Buy this game you won't regret it."

reviewText:
This is my opinion.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is like an art to me. It really captured the sense of Russia in an apocalyptic stage. It has some open world elements to is with a very good story. It might seem a little old for the new gamers but once you get in to it than I’ll think they will share my vision.

The coolest part of the staler series I think is the psy damage you can take. That moment there is some kind of anomaly that makes you insane, making you hear voices and makes you see things there aren’t there. And the emisions  make you feel like you have to outrun a nuclear explosion. next to that there are more kids of damages you could receive like burns, poison damage, bleeding damage, radiation, starvation, shock damage, Rupture (from mutants animals), and explosion damage.

The mutants are quite scary and you can always hear them from a far adding to the horror element of the game. Some mutants turn invisible and become visible again once close to you trying to suck you blood. Other mutants try to control you brain. And that really makes me ♥♥♥♥ bricks.

Call of Pripyat is one is one of the few series that S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has to offer. What I did miss in the game was the ability to join factions just like in S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear sky.
I really do recommend the game.

reviewText:
Why does monolith call?

I got fallout 3 right when it came out and every expansion when available as well. I thought that was the epitome of survival wasteland fps/rpg gaming. Then I find this stalker shadow of Chernobyl game and think generic knockoff. After going through stalker 1.0 with all the weird bugs however, I soon realized this was fallout on steroids.

The mood of the game, the difficulty (initially), even the lighting was exceptional. Also, what I'd call the rpg elements of getting better gear felt more natural as opposed to leveling stats on my guy in fallout. Walking around the metro shooting ghouls with the terrible shotgun whilst paused in v.a.t.s. pales in comparison to going into the labs around Chernobyl. Chernobyl had zombies but also included cloaking bloodsuckers lurking behind you, snorks ready to pounce, a behemoth flesh creature, along with mutated dogs, poltergeists, and various other startling abominations.

Clear sky brought in the interesting concept of modifying weapons and factions. That was about all Clear Sky offered save for an upgrade to the Xray engine. Oddly enough, the factions were lost with the next installment

Now with the most refined version of Call of Pripyat what was interesting before is even better.  Hunting in anomalies for artifacts using a detection device and throwing bolts is a very interesting way of essentially mining the environment. Secret stashes that can be found at any time without prerequisite was a good addition.

Call of Pripyat also saw a better structured campaign. SoC was too loose, CS was to linear, CoP to me is just right. Though don't get me wrong the game in all iterations is open roaming, but CS felt like walking through levels and SoC had areas of no interest.

I've just been playing a heavily modified Call of Pripyat and it's almost like a new game again. the mods give it a high replay ability factor.

Sneaking into a mercenary base and taking out heavy geared mercs then looting everything is oddly satisfying. Then, trying to walk back in complete darkness to sell loot with all manner of hostile creatures about is icing on the cake.

I recommend anyone interested in good games to play this.

reviewText:
If I had to choose between the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games, I'd pick Call of Pripyat. Many good features from the previous games have been polished such as trading, upgrading items, combat, artifact detection and collection, and even questing. The plot and ending really got to me.

The open world is an issue. The pacing of progression between questing areas is a bit of a different flavor from previous games. In Call of Pripyat, your progress between zones is limited by story progression. This is in contrast to SoC where your exploration was (mostly) only limited by progressively more difficult opponents and anomalies. On the other hand, while CoP locks you into a zone, it's not exactly a small space. Later in the game, you'll even find yourself with reasons to go back to previous areas for bonuses and min/maxing.

The RPG element has been well polished as well. The importance of your equipment choices cannot be understated. With a wide variety of weapons, armor, attachments and modification trees (like talent trees!), consumables, and artifacts(stat altering) your options are quite vast. There are many situations in the game where the proper equipment can turn a fevered fight for survival into a even back and fourth or perhaps little challange at all.

As a STALKER game it would be poor form for me not to comment on the atmosphere. This is something I feel Call of Pripyat, like it's predecessors, did very well. At a glace, some may see only a melancholy dystopia sprinkled with shock and a little horror, but there's so much more to it. While the darkness and gloom are very evident, beneath the surface lies the subtle thrill of being on the edge of an unexplored frontier with somthing to discover around every corner. You never know who or what you'll run into next.

The themes behind the game and STALKER in general are fairly mature. For all the good in the game, it's still (IMO) dark, gritty, and brutally honest about might" and it's connection to what is "right". There is good in this world
date: but it's few and far between. As for the plot
recommended: it certainly helps to have experience in the previous games. From the get-go you're aware your character's motivation is ethically dubious at best. To his credit
hoursPlayed: the MC grows and confronts these issues making him seem more relatable.\n\nIf you want a full experience I recommend you play the previous STALKER games first. There are plenty of references and even an important character or two. Problem is
voteText: I don't believe any of these games have aged particularly well graphically or mechanically. But if you can suffer though some imperfections
helpfulPercent: the experience is worth it.\n\nOne final and important note
votesHelpful: there are some good mods for Call of Pripyat as well as previous games. If you manage to get though the game
votesTotal: modding is definitely a way to expand re-playability."

reviewText: I am so very torn by this game it's unreal. I can't love this game and yet I want to, I can't hate it and yet I want to. I suppose I was just so excited at the premise of an open world shooter set in Pripyat, the idea alone is worth so much and yet I find myself ambivalent. It's really fun to explore the dark, depressing but not tense world of post-Chernobyl Pripyat (and the outlying areas, you don't actually REACH Pripyat until much later) but it feels so sparse. I know you'd expect that sort of thing from an irradiated area but it feels like a few meagre locations interspersed with mostly identical grassland with the occasional swamp or trees or anomaly, it works from a canonical standpoint but I feel it cheapens the whole open world" aspect. The almost utter lack of voice acting prbably wouldn't have bothered me so much except it makes it impossible to distinguish people. They have no personality of which to speak and whatever voice acting you DO get is at best okay (sometimes you can CLEARLY hear the same person switch between two different voice actors

reviewText:
now this wont be a full reveiw upon first writing but im going over the baisics of what i want to say ( becuase ive got a dam lot to say about this game i mean look at this intro :D )

The S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Series as always been my favourite series of games for a number of reasons, whether it is the crazy amount of weird and wonderful guns, suits and items, or the weird and whacky storyline, i love almost everything about this game , and i will say why now.

Story:
one of my favourite parts about the stalker games is the story lines that always seem to have a big twist at the end or something like that. Anyway, the story in CoP is really quite cool how they made it all play out, one of the best bits is being able to see how you affected every other stalkers life while you were in the zone at the end of the game with about 20 or so slides telling you about what happend after you left the zone.

Weaponry:
With a decent selection of weaponry for all play styles, this game can make you play through it many times just so you can play around with the guns and ammo types ( two for each gun except the PKM, Sniper rifles and the RPG ). from shotguns to expermental gaus rifles, this game unmodded provided me with atleast 70 hours before i even thought about modding it.

Suits / Armour:
Stalker has system whereby you can wear suits that affect your carry weight, protection for various envriomental hazards, gunfire and can effect your mobility. CoP by far offers the most diverse Suit system by allowing the player to (with most suits) mix and match head gear and main body suits depending on your play style, (gas masks for artifact hunters, military helmets for combat, and high-end mixes of both). There is a massive variety of upgrades that can completley changes the suits performance (Servos on an exoskeleton, alloying you to sprint).

Upgrading your equipment:
CoP allows you to collect tool kits and gie them to technicians, who will reward you with the ability to upgrade your guns and suits more (and a small cash reward). You can turn a AK-74 into a laser fast firing assault cannon, or make it a more accurate mid range sniper.

reviewText:
--This is a neutral review from someone who is not familiar with the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series--

S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a series I really want to get into because the community isn't stupid and the game looks damn good but the older S.T.A.L.K.E.R games are a bit to old for my liking so I got this one becuase its the latest.

Now I tried to get into this game, I really did but Christicle on a bicycle this is hard, the game gives you a little bit of backstory and then dumps you in a field. This appears to be one of those games that you learn about the hard way, for example every now and then something called an Emission explodes across the whole map and wipes out everyone, I found myself getting killed over and over again by the first Emission until I eventually gave up and Googled it, I discovered that you have to hide underground in order to escape it...I guess this is just the cruel nature of this game because it gives you little to no information on anything, not even the basic mechanics are revealed to you and you have to study up everything just like Dark Souls.

The atmosphere in this game is astonishing and I have never seen a game come even close to the dark, creepy and radioactive atmosphere that this game has, I spent most of my time too afriad to enter buildings because of the various sanity destroying sounds coming out of them.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat is a game I really want to get into but the difficulty and various mechanics that I know nothing about keeps scaring me away from it. Some people say that this game is a Fallout 3 ripoff and I find that really offensive because the developers must of worked really hard on this game and I feel like they didn't get the respect/money that they deserved because this game is different and somewhat ahead of its time.

Now get out of here Stalker!

reviewText:
And now, the final part of the stalker revisions...Call of Pripyat. To remind my readers, this is now based on the vanilla experience, as this will conclude the 3 stalker games' revisions.

What can i say about this game? Was it fun? Yes. Was it more sandbox-y than Clear Sky? Yes. Did it feel empty and hollow? You bet. For all the mechanics that the developers improved upon they possibly refined a little too much, to the point that the streamlined gameplay somehow made the game easier. This is Stalker we are talking about here. It's not supposed to be easy.....is it? Even on Master skill this game was easier than Clear Sky or Shadow of Chernobyl on Stalker (Medium) skill. The developers improved the upgrade mechanic, to where you no longer need to fetch flash drives and bring them to the respective mechanics. Instead, you're left with finding tools in each of the first 2 maps to bring to the mechanics, and then have to travel to Pripyat to find the last of the tools. Not quite as tedious to some, but still requires you to do some work.

The graphics in my opinion took a step in the wrong direction. While the lighting may have improved a little with the DirectX 11 renderer, most of everything else seemed like it was ripped from SoC in terms of quality. Maybe this had to do with the larger, albeit fewer, maps. Honestly, i really couldn't tell much of a difference at all between DX 9 and 11, aside from a little improved lighting. The characters still have the same facial animations, reload animations, etc....

The sound was vastly improved,and while the sound effects still aren't of a caliber as say Battlefield, they do the job. Now, when the emissions hit, however, the sound design improves because it brings back the creepy vibe of SoC. When i first loaded the game up and experienced my first emission, just the sound of the storm brewing and approaching was haunting. I was running for cover as if I PERSONALLY was going to die.

The gameplay mechanics stay intact from the other 2 games, except your character feels too much like a bullet sponge. Enemies go down rather quickly, yet, you can take several shots without too much worry, as long as you have a relatively good armor suit. The emissions respawn artifacts, allowing you to continue artifact hunting in anomalies you already cleared. However, this brings more money to you. Sell the artifacts, make a bunch of money, buy an exoskeleton suit in the first map......wait...what? That's right, you can buy an exo suit from Nimble very quickly in this game if you have the funds for it. Not really that difficult to have the funds for it with the abundance of artifacts and the side objectives having a wealthy payout. Now, i know that some gamers would say, then don't buy the exo suit." Not the point. The point is
date: as i stated in my review for Clear Sky
recommended: what made that game so well constructed was the pacing and balance. By Nimble giving you access to an exo suit and top notch weaponry from the get-go

reviewText:
And now, the final part of the stalker revisions...Call of Pripyat. To remind my readers, this is now based on the vanilla experience, as this will conclude the 3 stalker games' revisions.

What can i say about this game? Was it fun? Yes. Was it more sandbox-y than Clear Sky? Yes. Did it feel empty and hollow? You bet. For all the mechanics that the developers improved upon they possibly refined a little too much, to the point that the streamlined gameplay somehow made the game easier. This is Stalker we are talking about here. It's not supposed to be easy.....is it? Even on Master skill this game was easier than Clear Sky or Shadow of Chernobyl on Stalker (Medium) skill. The developers improved the upgrade mechanic, to where you no longer need to fetch flash drives and bring them to the respective mechanics. Instead, you're left with finding tools in each of the first 2 maps to bring to the mechanics, and then have to travel to Pripyat to find the last of the tools. Not quite as tedious to some, but still requires you to do some work.

The graphics in my opinion took a step in the wrong direction. While the lighting may have improved a little with the DirectX 11 renderer, most of everything else seemed like it was ripped from SoC in terms of quality. Maybe this had to do with the larger, albeit fewer, maps. Honestly, i really couldn't tell much of a difference at all between DX 9 and 11, aside from a little improved lighting. The characters still have the same facial animations, reload animations, etc....

The sound was vastly improved,and while the sound effects still aren't of a caliber as say Battlefield, they do the job. Now, when the emissions hit, however, the sound design improves because it brings back the creepy vibe of SoC. When i first loaded the game up and experienced my first emission, just the sound of the storm brewing and approaching was haunting. I was running for cover as if I PERSONALLY was going to die.

The gameplay mechanics stay intact from the other 2 games, except your character feels too much like a bullet sponge. Enemies go down rather quickly, yet, you can take several shots without too much worry, as long as you have a relatively good armor suit. The emissions respawn artifacts, allowing you to continue artifact hunting in anomalies you already cleared. However, this brings more money to you. Sell the artifacts, make a bunch of money, buy an exoskeleton suit in the first map......wait...what? That's right, you can buy an exo suit from Nimble very quickly in this game if you have the funds for it. Not really that difficult to have the funds for it with the abundance of artifacts and the side objectives having a wealthy payout. Now, i know that some gamers would say, then don't buy the exo suit." Not the point. The point is

reviewText:
If you enjoy fps style games with more involving rpg style content then the Stalker trilogy is worth a look. The  games also have a thriving modding community with everything from texture enhancing mods to total rebuilds. The Moddb site holds a good variety of examples such as high difficulty mods like Misery to Russian classics like AMK and SGM. You'll find a good selection of Russian All-in-ones that include English translations on the following Moddb pages.
Go to:

http://www.moddb.com/members/davidme

or the Translated Russian mods page:

reviewText: So here I am recommending Stalker Call of Pripyat, probably the last Stalker game that will have been produced. So Stalker Call of Pripyat is a fantastic Post-apocalyptic first person shooter taken place in the Zone of Alienation AKA The Zone". Stalker Call of Pripyat is the third stalker game and features items and weapons not featured in the other Stalker games. Stalker Call of Pripyat is about a Ex-Stalker and now Military "Major Alexander Degtyarev". The major's mission is to follow the investigation of "Operation Fairway" and why it failed. Stalker Call of Pripyat is very well optimized and well made for all types of machines! The game does not feature many bugs as for maybe some crashes due to loading issues and graphical issue with mods. Mods! Oh yes
date: oh yes. The mods currently out for Stalker Call of Pripyat are fantastic to completely overhauling the game's graphics to makeing the game extremely hard! In conclusion: Stalker Call of Pripyat is one of the best games I've personally played
recommended: it never ceases to amaze and keep me from being bored. It has an amazing modding community! Stalker CoP may have a crash here and there
hoursPlayed: but it never disappoints me! Stalker Call of Pripyat deserves it's price."

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorate games. The ambiance in it is unparalelled if you removed all the enemies in it you'd still be on edge no matter where you were in it. Expecially if you add the Misery mod. That mod makes you know if you get in a fight that you are not prepared for you will die and even if you prepared and planned for what ever came at you things can still go so bad so quickly. I give this a 10/10 for being a challange and keeping you on edge no matter what.

But it does have bad things about it such as the lag. As you play it seems like theres less and less lag expecially if you hang around relatively the same areas. I read up on what causes the lag and it's supposidly the AI activating and deactivating as you move accross the map.

But even with the momentary freezing and lag its still and epic game alway keeps you on edge and aways a fun challenge trying to survive the horrors of chernobol.

reviewText: By itself, Call of Pripyat is alright and mostly recommendable - way better than Clear Sky, but still far from delivering on the original promise of the STALKER concept. As all of them, CoP is genuinely at its best when you're left to roam freely, explore, scavenge, pick your own battles and soak in the atmosphere. The linear parts of the game are forgettable and the graphics, well, I guess there the engine is starting to show it's age. But it's pretty alright.\n\nHowever, the Misery mod for Call of Pripyat makes it an absolute hardcore survival masterpiece. It is by far the toughest, most fully-featured, and mercilessly dreary single-player survivor shooter out there - nothing comes even close. It always walks that fine line between jaw-droppingly challenging, frightening and just kind of stupidly insane, and that definitely makes it not everyone's cup of tea. The name doesn't lie - you can say a lot of things about Misery, but it's hard to call it fun". It is a game out to murder you

reviewText:
Hands down the best entry in the serie, i've enjoyed it a lot more than the original. Taking all the best features of Clear Sky and Shadow of Chernobyl on a single package, they got all the elements in the series just right with this game

Graphically it looks the same as Clear Sky with some improved effects and texturing, and yeah it plays the same than previous stalker games but adding a lot of great features. Also, its bug free compared to clear sky, the game is definitely polished in all areas and does the one thing a game in any genre should do... and that is the grin factor. How much does it make you want to play again and again.

They also refined various elements that add value, no more fast money for selling ♥♥♥♥, you can't sell items below 75% damage. At the start you may find this a real pain and seek some kind of mod to reverse this, after playing through I feel it benefits to the desired role of artifacts and weapon value in the story.

I hope there may be some light on the horizon called S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 in a near future, its a shame cause they were doing it right

My veredict.. 9/10, amazing game.

Excellent FPS Adventure, game starts out strongly but somewhat flats out like B-movie near the end. Neverthless, it's worth playing. At the beginning Player has to build up equipment and relations to NPCs before excursing to the city of Pripyat. First part of the game is well done and offers lot of side quests and adventuring. Upon reaching Pripyat game is quite shortlived, but trip is worth seeing. However, be prepared for disappoitment: famous Pripyat Ferris Wheel is only seen at the distance.

Game environments are very meticulously done and artistic work reflects a lot of CCCP-times mindset. Radioactive Zone seems to be frozen in the time, there is nothing but melancholy and decay.

Downsides are minor interface issues and somewhat short game story. Also I would have liked to see more populous mutated monster hordes.

8/10, good game.

reviewText:
The third installment in the series and clearly the superior in manny ways.

The only problem I have with Call of Pripyat is the lack of exploration, and since I played each STALKER game in order I feel that this one reverted from the progress they made from 1st to the 2nd game in the series.

reviewText:
TOTALLY RECOMMENDED - if you are not afraid of some scary and lonely moments in the zone. People are not friendly in this game, nor should you be. In this game you will learn to survive, thinking only for yourself.

I bought it recently because this game has a really good rating on steam. I played S.T.A.L.K.E.R.  Shadow of Chernobil - so I'm not new to this genre.

I downloaded it, installed it (and because its from 2010) I also installed the misery 2.1.1 mod from moddb. It enhances the game with nice updated graphics but also includes a lot of ingame content/changes (very recommended)

What did I receive for my money?

A scary, dark game. Ultra high difficulty level. its no more 'learning the game' - 'EZ frags'. Its f****** damn hard to play now. It's a real challenge. Many quests, some you start, and you dont really know, what will happen. Very deep feelings, very atmospheric.  If you took some russian lessions in CS:GO, this one is like the final exam.

I also want to mention, that this game is an offline-RPG game (even-though it has a multiplayer-deathmatch like thing). So its a game you can enjoy for hours, when internet is not availlable.

Cheers.

reviewText:
After spending more than a year playing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games I finally completed the trilogy.  It took me so long, I think, because I was almost afraid to play the games sometimes.  Not in a scary game sort of way but in a I-never-want-this-to-end sort of way.  I didn't want to proceed until I felt I'd fully absorbed certain elements of the story.  The choices you are forced to make in the games are compelling and have had a lasting effect on me.  I'm am a little sad that the journey is over for now.

CoP seemed to differ from the previous games in that it was a fair amount more approachable to newcomers.  The first two games were unforgiving and had a marginally tough learning curve.  GSC prettied up the HUD a little, which made managing your character less of a chore.  But the gameplay was still the awesome gameplay from the first two games and the story was just as compelling as SoC.

I can't recommend these games enough.  Play them now.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call Of Pripyat:

S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call Of Pripyat is a sequel to S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow Of Chernobyl, but has very little to do with the prequel except for the gameplay similarities and that they both are located in ''The Zone'' which is the irradiated area  surrounding the nuclear power plant Chernobyl and the city of Pripyat in Ukraine, needless to say, other than that the whole scenario is fictional. S.T.A.L.K.E.R is a Horror/Survival FP Shooter game developed by GSC Game World.

General Information and story:

You start as an USS Major Degtyarev and you are sent in to ''The Zone'' to investigate a failed operation called ''Operation Fairway''. This operation was planned to take the the Chernobyl NPP by force from the current forces holding it known only by the name ''Monolith''. The operation was a failure and all the stingray helicopters crashed in a suspicious way. So there you  are and you're mission is clear, but as you advance in the story it gets everything but clear, the pilots that are dead or killed all died in an extraordinary way except for those who died by the impact of the crashing helicopter, and some of the helicopters appear to be disfuctional even before they hit the ground.
You're mission is a solo effort to find out why Operation Fairway was a failure, but as you progress through The Zone you have to work among the local stalkers which are the people wondering around and exploring The Zone brought there by various reasons. You may choose to work alongside the stalkers or rob them as a bandit either way you will have buddies. Stalkers make the most money, which is a luxury in The Zone, by hunting Artifacts which are items formed in an anomalous area, after getting artifacts they sell them to traders who trade them to the outside world. Artifacts have strange abilities like healing abilities. The Zone is a strange and dangerous place which makes the majors mission anything but easy. The Zone is full of dangerous anomalies, radiation, bandits, madmen, criminals and even mutated animals and people!
You're mission leads you to the center of The Zone to city of Pripyat where you meet up with the remaining soldiers from Operation Fairway, There you can choose to do something about the Monolith and soon find out more about how the helicopters crashed. As it turns out the monolith have a secret weapon which works with electric energy from artifacts and uses batteries for ''magazines'' the weapon is called Gauss Rifle and the helicopters were shot down. in the end you are given a option to leave The Zone or to find out more about the Gauss Rifle and the Monolith or about The Zone, so the story is only so good how mutch time you put in to it. Like any other game you can just rush it out or take time with it and S.T.A.L.K.E.R is one where you should totally invest some time otherwise it's easily looked over because of it's graphical issues and it's cheap look, but the truth is S.T.A.L.K.E.R is anything but cheap! It may lack a perfect story but the atmosphere and feel is like any other, S.T.A.L.K.E.R has many intersting side missions and stories and the fact that it loosely is related to reality and has a realistic feel to it makes it an unmatched expirience in this kind of genre.

Gameplay:

Gameplay of S.T.A.L.K.E.R is very unique in my oppinion, it combines FPS gameplay with survival elements such as hunger and radiation sickness and the need to sleep with horror and even RPG elements such as simple stats, different weapons and armor, economy, side missions and exploring. Combined with the enviroment the gameplay fits like a glove even if it has a few downsides. The downsides are mostly minor things such as repeated lines from NPC's and buggy animations, other than that it's O.K. All in all the gameplay is something quite different from other compareable games and in a good way! S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call Of Pripyat can attract fans of many genres. Multiplayer is nothing special, you're typical DM, TDM witch areas from the singleplayer.

Graphics:

The game was first released in 2009 so the graphics are a bit old but i wouldn't say that they look terrible, they aren't the diamond either there is a lot of room for improvement in here but especially in the animations. The game uses the X-Ray engine and has been updated to version 1.6 with DirectX 11. The games graphics can be enhanced with several mods that are avaliable through the web. I haven't found any major problems that mods have not been able to fix.

Other:

One thing that must be said about Call Of Pripyat is the large quantity of different mods that are avaliable, apparently S.T.A.L.K.E.R fans are loyal to game and have made a lot of great mods for people to play. Allmost every problem and aspect of the game can be fixed/enhanced with large or small mods. I recommend playing the game with one major mod before declaring it a piece of trash.

Verdict:

S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call Of Pripyat is  allmost a ground breaking title. Call Of Pripyat lacks the appearence to catch peoples eyes but is a beautyful game in many aspects. S.T.A.L.K.E.R in my oppinion has no problems the mods can't fix. All in all it is a refreshing title and a great expirience for a fan of any genre and has a feel and atmosphere like any other. Story is nothing special but keeps you interested to the end plus S.T.A.L.K.E.R has many great side missions. You can easily put 40 to 50 hours to this game and still not have played every little bit, depending on your difficulty and playstyle of course.
S.T.A.L.K.E.R Call of Pripyat is excellent singleplayer expirience!

9/10

reviewText: Call of Pripyat's a brilliant game that's definitely worth the 20 someodd hours it takes to beat it. It's an often intense, very dangerous shooter that actually forces you to use your head and pay attention to the game. Every enemy is incredibly dangerous, and the details are all quite well thought out. The game is also completely gorgeous and feels pleasant. You have a ton of freedom to pursue any and every goal at your whim, as you're dropped into Ukraine with nothing but a map, a mission, and some basic gear. There are plenty of ways to deal with your problems, and plenty of actually worthwhile challenges to take on. All done and bored with this game? There are a ton of mods to look into, most notably being MISERY. I haven't tried that as of yet though. Definitely worth a gander considering the price.

reviewText: I've played a lot of games. A LOT of games. This one, however, is special. I can't quite tell you why. The controls were clunky at times, the graphics were nothing awe inspiring, hell, the voice acting was terrible. It has this attraction though. Perhaps the sci-fi lore, or the freedom to do as I please in a world that feels the same freedom. Treasure hunting artifacts in hazardous areas, or trying to consolidate all the loot from all the people i've killed, or cautiously entering dark rooms with who knows what kind of mutated horror. The company is dead, and so is the game, but I will NEVER forget ths one.

reviewText:
Originally posted on December 26, 2010

After being let down by Clear Sky's unfinished gameplay, I was wary of Call of Pripyat, and although the game is beginning to seem a bit dated, it is still tons of fun.

Graphics-
The game looks both technically artistically brilliant. While the engine is beginning to show its age outdoors at long distances, the lighting effects, foliage, clouds, and especially the decaying urban environments all look fantastic. I have only played the game maxed with DX10, so I can't attest to how great the DX11 features look. However, even so, the game looks and plays phenomenally.

Sound-
The music and atmospheric noises are as good as ever, and the voice acting is decent, which is good for a game from Ukraine.

Gameplay-
They've really integrated features that worked from Clear Sky with features from Shadow of Chernobyl. You can upgrade weapons and repair them, using special calibration tools (which are a bit too difficult to find), but ballistics feels much more like it did in the first, and the focus is much less on combat with humans and much more on exploring and finding mutants. Factions are in place, but no one will attack you on sight unless you've made an enemy of them. Even bandits. This makes for some interesting interactions out in the wild. There are now blowouts which require you to hide indoors or you will die. Gone is the wonky factional combat from clear sky, and perhaps most importantly, gone are the bugs, glitches, crashes, and other instability issues. That stability is what makes Call of Pripyat so refined.

The story is weaker compared to the first, but it is still quite good, and the atmosphere of the game itself is great. If you liked STALKER, you won't be disappointed by Call of Pripyat. That being said, I'm expecting big things from STALKER 2. They've had plenty of time to refine their formula and train their skills. Now it's time to shine.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Third part in the STALKER series.\nSTALKER Call Of Pripyat brings out into the light Major Alexander Degtyarev.The protagonist is an agent for the Ukraine Security Service and his(your) task is to investigate the failure of the mission Operation Fairway". You start undercover in a new area of The Zone and you're immediately sent into surviving since there is a long way until your first objective and safe area.\nThe game picks up from where STALKER SoC left it and has improved graphics
date: map size and keeps all the changes Clear Sky had.\nIn CoP the devs removed the quests for data required for upgrading your gear and they added tools that the mechanics can use(read the quests for instructions where to find them or Google it ). The user can easily explore and he can find hidden stashes no matter if they have or don't have the coords on his PDA.The game has only 3 huge areas with good quests
hoursPlayed: underground laboratories
voteText:
new weapons and new information the military has left behind.It's your decision what to do with the information found and who do you want to help.
At the end of the game the user encounters a familiar face that brings the knowlege of The Zone.

Pros
-Exoskeleton can now be upgraded and the user can run. ( later in the game )
- Wonderful quests and new beautiful areas.
- More nice stuff you don't want to miss
- Work for what you want.

Cons
- Only 3 areas
-Almost impossible to achieve good ending final mission being too hard.

A true STALKER has no cons.

I recommend that the user does all the quests for the full experience Call of Pripyat offers and I also recommend that you play this as vanilla for the best STALKER experience then you can mod it and have fun.

Order of gameplay - STALKER CLEAR SKY -> STALKER SHADOW OF CHERNOBYL -> STALKER CALL OF PRIPYAT

Order of appearance - STALKER SHADOW OF CHERNOBYL - STALKER CLEAR SKY - STALKER CALL OF PRIPYAT

Watch your back STALKER>

reviewText:
After spending more than a year playing the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games I finally completed the trilogy.  It took me so long, I think, because I was almost afraid to play the games sometimes.  Not in a scary game sort of way but in a I-never-want-this-to-end sort of way.  I didn't want to proceed until I felt I'd fully absorbed certain elements of the story.  The choices you are forced to make in the games are compelling and have had a lasting effect on me.  I'm am a little sad that the journey is over for now.

CoP seemed to differ from the previous games in that it was a fair amount more approachable to newcomers.  The first two games were unforgiving and had a marginally tough learning curve.  GSC prettied up the HUD a little, which made managing your character less of a chore.  But the gameplay was still the awesome gameplay from the first two games and the story was just as compelling as SoC.

I can't recommend these games enough.  Play them now.

reviewText: Although this game is great alone. With mods it is waaaay more enjoyable. Arsenal with 60 new armos and 200 new weapons is great. Atmosphere 3 is usually included with all of the larger mods. But, Misery. Dear God, Misery. It scares people off because its incredibly difficult. It shouldn't though, it's extremely immersive, letting you live an actual life in the zone, doing what you want to do as a Loner Stalker. Misery is if anything, playable forever, there is so much micromanaging, as far as waking up in the morning, planning on observing a certain area, deciding to go in for the kill, and planning your raid, to cleaning your weapon, to setting up camp for the night and just putting food on the table, to watching your radiation and other needs, to planning a hunting trip to make reap a god kill and harvest the goods. I've been playing this game for a long time, I live for immesive realism games, ArmA, DayZ, Ranger Hardcore on Metro, Master difficulty on the vanilla S.T.A.L.K.E.R., never have I actually woken up in real life, got showered, breakfast, etc. And decided to plan out my ingame day over a real life cup of coffee on a Saturday morning. If you want something real, something that makes you feel like you have to earn it, all of these games, you play ♥♥♥ the main character, gunslinging, medkit addicted, bullet eating protagonist with a misson and everyone stepping out of your way for your story the world revolving around you. But not Misery, in Misery your just some everyday stalker, walking in eating your flesh (the ingame monster) bacon wrapped in brown papar to keep the grease from dripping (actual description, immersion is life) planning on going for that artifact today, or that camp, the rounds your taking for your gun, the equipment you'll need for that area, maybe a sleeping bag and a safe place, incase youre out ill nightfall or an emission happens all of the sudden. In order to be a badass gunslinging veteran stalker, you had to train yourself and learn to be a badass stalker, absolutely no handholding in the mod. Misery will make you feel like you're there, but its not for everybody, the mod is infamously difficult, harder than Dark Souls, harder than the original Ninja Gaiden (well maybe not THAT hard *cringes at Ninja Gaiden*), at any moment something could leap from the marshes or shadows, whether it be a enemy stalker bullet, or the claws of a bloodsucker, if you're not on your toes with some real friggin' reflexes, you will die. A lot of times, no matter how good you are, sometimes you just get unlucky and a stary bullet will nail your head ending your journey in the zone. If your a serious immersion freak, wondering how you would really do in the zone (with basic knowledge of weaponry and cooking and medicenes) Misery is for you. If you like things tough, but still want to be a bit on top of everything else, try Master difficulty with Arenal Overload. However, the game is enjoyable and incredible regardless, 10/10!

reviewText:
Call of Pripyat is a game that is a natural sequel to ShoC. Although it has fewer areas to explore, the amount of detail in each is staggering and the design is much more open, leading to less running into fences and what not. The addition of Blowouts is a great touch, and the roleplaying takes a queue from Fallout this time around, lending itself to more decisions on how to side with, and the benefits for doing so.

You can also repair weapons and the mods you can acquire are much, much more numerous and functional, beyond simple silencer + scope + gl. A lot of dummied out features make a return, from unused weapons, armor, enemise, and lore-elements. The anomalies are also much more dangerous.

Again, the AI is a complaint. It is equal parts smart (dogs will form packs against you and hunt you down, human ai will flank you) and dumb (human ai in an emission has weird priorities, choosing to casually walk to safe cover rather than running like mad).

Well worth the purchase.

reviewText: This game is a jewel of the genre of apocalyptic games, and escpecially S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. UI is practical and simple, storyline is very good (but wish it was longer), new graphics engine really brings the game to the table. And that atmosphere....This is why S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games have fans all around the world. The atmosphere in this game is simply amazing, it makes you want to put hundreds and hundreds of hours of gameplay even after you finish the game.Great thing is that this series has also a very big modding community, so it is always interesting to play. Be that a graphics/weather mods (i.e. Atmosfear 3), arsenal mods, overall improvment of the game (Complete mod), or global mods which create an entirely new storyline. There are easily a couple of hundred hours on this game. I would recommend it to everyone, especially people who like post-apocalyptic genre, realism, atmosphere, and simply a well made game.\nMy rating: 15 out of 10.
