reviewText:
STALKER is basically Fallout's perpetually-grim alcoholic Ukrainian cousin who happens to have an avid, borderline-obsessive interest in mutated animals and bloated psychic dwarfs clad in oversized robes. (Believe me, they're a lot more intimidating than you might believe!)

Essentially, STALKER is a highly atmospheric FPS sandbox with a lot of survival mechanics (the need to eat, manage wounds and radiation sickness, etc.) that also includes some horror elements. (Although I believe the original - Shadow of Chernobyl - was focused on horror more than CoP is)

Overall it can be a very tense experience. I would certainly recommend picking this up if you like shooters that go off the beaten track and have quite a unique world to explore, as Call of Pripyat has done exactly that!

reviewText: Arguably this is the best of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, either this or clear sky. Clear sky is longer, but more flawed.  This game is shorter, and is only 3 areas (really, REALLY big areas), but the game feels more alive.  The quests are better overall, and for once you get to form a group of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s, although only for one mission (nothing like the zombie mission from Clear Sky).  The mutants are scarier than ever, and the new chimera is a fearsome beast.  The origins of the monolith faction are finally clearly explained (although clever players knew what was up already).  If you haven't beaten clear sky then the true origins of the zone will remain a mystery to you in this game, with a cursory intro and a couple of dialogue options here and there being your only explanation (although it is not at all central to the plot).  The plot is fairly weak, but fun so it doesn't really matter.  what is really good is the world crafting, it is really fun just running around collecting artifacts, hunting mutants, and completing misssions.  Collecting and upgrading different guns can also be really fun, but experienced players will quickly find some guns are Much better than others.  The atmosphere and sound is top notch, I highly recommend if you like environmental horror games and fps games.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Pripyat is crawling with a mixture of radiation and artifacts. Emissions hit one after another, and there's always mutants and anomalies to watch out for... Welcome to Hell. A blend of First Person Shooting and Role Playing Game elements make you choose what little to take on your next raid. Every day is a survive-it-or-not challenge, and I hope you brought your anomaly detector with you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The last piece in the Stalker trilogy. The Zone is ever so dangerous, and emissions happen every now and then. In this final chapter the game isnt so different. Although the gameplay area is totally new consisting of three big maps (it is smaller than its predecessors, so the storyline is shorter), there are few other changes since the last game. Call of Pripyat is propably the most stable one of the three, which is a good thing.
The Protagonist is part of a military investigation, but he is not considered enemy among other stalkers. The main storyline mission is about finding the remains of crashed military helicopters, and determing what happened to them. Of course there are lots of side missions, and places to visit just for laughs. The CNPP is not involved in the game, instead the final destination is the city of Pripyat.
There are less mods made to this game, probably because it is the newest in the gameseries, but most of the mods are compatible with the steam version, and they will enhance the gameplay experience quite a bit.
Definitely better than Clear Sky but cant compete with Shadow of Chernobyl.

reviewText:
This is a Fallout set near to Chernyobil zone, where game takes action.
As a result to this, game has 3 large sectors to explore, post soviet assets (buildings, environment and etc) and of course STALKERS! You have some task to do (that's why you arrived here), and you do it. But same as Skyrim, you can just forget about it, and do whatever you want. You can pick up some detector tool, take some medkits and go look for artifacts in anomalies, while finding your path between bone-crushing/acid-melting/electricity-striking/etc anomalies by throwing metallic bolts. All this to find artefacts - some usual objects which got abnormal effects due to being in proximity of anomaly. And then you sell them, get better gear, get better at finding artefacts, help local factions in their wars, get some bandit ♥♥♥ kicked, drink vodka while planning very dangerous expedition, find crashed UAV, headshot zombies and run from pseudogiants....

So, basically like Skyrim with guns and stalkers. And as mentioned in other reviews, nobody tells you what to do. You will have to figure out everything - how to find artefacts, where and how to fix and upgrade guns (sometimes they can't upgrade your gun because of being sober) and etc...

Good luck, stalker.

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat could best be described as a mixture between Fallout, Metro 2033, and a touch of Mount and Blade. This game does not hold your hand, you are thrusted into the chaotic world of post-apocalyptic Russia with no tutorials or even goals given. It is easy enough to figure out how to follow the main quest, and side missions aren't revealed with an exclamation point over the quest-giver's head. The gunplay is surprisingly impressive as your weapons will break the more you shoot. Enemies are somewhat creative though they can become an annoyance as they are sometimes tough to shoot. But all in all, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is definitely worth a try.

reviewText: I have smashed out over 100 hours on this game, but not recorded on steam. This game, while somewhat shorter than Shadow of Chernobyl (what I found anyway) is also a lot less buggy, very few in fact that I encounted. Very smooth and this game also has a tight story that is put together well and has great weapons, characters, as well as voices being good and of course you have choice! You learn quickly not to just shoot on sight and also there are moments you need to get into cover, makes night hunting a little more nerve racking, because of emissions that can kill instantly. I really enjoyed the stealth and weapon modifications as well as the side quests and character quests. Also, there are amazing mods that just massively improve the gameplay to push it to the most amazing experience possible! A great ending if done right.

reviewText:
While an enjoyable game on its own, this game can support various mods to greatly expand its horizons.
Suggested mods -
1.    MISERY - for its challenge and great amount of added content.
2.    Call of Chernobyl - for all the locations added from each game, although quest content is low, there is still plenty to explore, collect, loot and shoot, with the mod creators updating it periodically. This is a freeplay mod, essentially.
Both mods can be found on Moddb.

Both of the above mods make the bloodsuckers almost always invisible when engaged, with no shimmer.

This game does have some unintentional jump scares.


The only drawbacks are the infrequent game crashes.

I would recommend this game. One of the interesting parts of the game is just in exploring the underground labs and abandoned bases.

reviewText: The STALKER series is notorious for being an amaziing immersive astmospheric mix of FPS, RPG and Horror. Call of Pripyat is by far the best in the series when it comes to guns and ccombat. Finding a gun you really like and being able to upgrade your weapon to how you want and putting your life and trust into one gun to help survive out in the harsh world of STALKER makes the atmosphere and immersion far beyond any FPS game has ever even came close to. The world of Pripyat makes for a great RPG and creepy atmoshere. Creeping around at night in the dark with all the horrible sounds going on around you makes you really appreciate a good atmosphere in a game and also that your gun is fully loaded and your reflexes are fast enough to be ready for what could be coming at your through the darkness at any moment. Open world and plenty of side quests and NPC to make for a great RPG and enough guns to keep you playing for hours. Although the story starts off pretty good, it ends pretty weak compared to Shadow of Chernobyl, which has an amazing story with 13 endings! DDo yourself a favor and buy the whole series and then download STALKER Complete for each game. These are bug fix mods and tweaks. They fix most if the major glitches and problems the vanilla games have. Also, check out LURK ffor Shadow Chernobyl and Misery for Call of Pripyat for the best possible way to play STALKER - Shadow of Chernoyble and STALKER Call of Pripyat.

reviewText: I have smashed out over 100 hours on this game, but not recorded on steam. This game, while somewhat shorter than Shadow of Chernobyl (what I found anyway) is also a lot less buggy, very few in fact that I encounted. Very smooth and this game also has a tight story that is put together well and has great weapons, characters, as well as voices being good and of course you have choice! You learn quickly not to just shoot on sight and also there are moments you need to get into cover, makes night hunting a little more nerve racking, because of emissions that can kill instantly. I really enjoyed the stealth and weapon modifications as well as the side quests and character quests. Also, there are amazing mods that just massively improve the gameplay to push it to the most amazing experience possible! A great ending if done right.

reviewText:
While an enjoyable game on its own, this game can support various mods to greatly expand its horizons.
Suggested mods -
1.    MISERY - for its challenge and great amount of added content.
2.    Call of Chernobyl - for all the locations added from each game, although quest content is low, there is still plenty to explore, collect, loot and shoot, with the mod creators updating it periodically. This is a freeplay mod, essentially.
Both mods can be found on Moddb.

Both of the above mods make the bloodsuckers almost always invisible when engaged, with no shimmer.

This game does have some unintentional jump scares.


The only drawbacks are the infrequent game crashes.

I would recommend this game. One of the interesting parts of the game is just in exploring the underground labs and abandoned bases.

reviewText:
The last piece in the Stalker trilogy. The Zone is ever so dangerous, and emissions happen every now and then. In this final chapter the game isnt so different. Although the gameplay area is totally new consisting of three big maps (it is smaller than its predecessors, so the storyline is shorter), there are few other changes since the last game. Call of Pripyat is propably the most stable one of the three, which is a good thing.
The Protagonist is part of a military investigation, but he is not considered enemy among other stalkers. The main storyline mission is about finding the remains of crashed military helicopters, and determing what happened to them. Of course there are lots of side missions, and places to visit just for laughs. The CNPP is not involved in the game, instead the final destination is the city of Pripyat.
There are less mods made to this game, probably because it is the newest in the gameseries, but most of the mods are compatible with the steam version, and they will enhance the gameplay experience quite a bit.
Definitely better than Clear Sky but cant compete with Shadow of Chernobyl.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Pripyat is crawling with a mixture of radiation and artifacts. Emissions hit one after another, and there's always mutants and anomalies to watch out for... Welcome to Hell. A blend of First Person Shooting and Role Playing Game elements make you choose what little to take on your next raid. Every day is a survive-it-or-not challenge, and I hope you brought your anomaly detector with you.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Arguably this is the best of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, either this or clear sky. Clear sky is longer, but more flawed.  This game is shorter, and is only 3 areas (really, REALLY big areas), but the game feels more alive.  The quests are better overall, and for once you get to form a group of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.s, although only for one mission (nothing like the zombie mission from Clear Sky).  The mutants are scarier than ever, and the new chimera is a fearsome beast.  The origins of the monolith faction are finally clearly explained (although clever players knew what was up already).  If you haven't beaten clear sky then the true origins of the zone will remain a mystery to you in this game, with a cursory intro and a couple of dialogue options here and there being your only explanation (although it is not at all central to the plot).  The plot is fairly weak, but fun so it doesn't really matter.  what is really good is the world crafting, it is really fun just running around collecting artifacts, hunting mutants, and completing misssions.  Collecting and upgrading different guns can also be really fun, but experienced players will quickly find some guns are Much better than others.  The atmosphere and sound is top notch, I highly recommend if you like environmental horror games and fps games.

reviewText:
There's nothing I can say about this game that wouldn't eventually devolve into me gobbling its balls like an overenthusiastic pac-man.

So here's a few of the bad things first.

● It is buggy, and it is unstable - especially during certian events. Save often.
● Some weapon iron sights are severely misaligned.
● Stealth is completely useless at medium to close ranges.
● Weapons degrade surprisingly quick, always have a backup.

Now for the good.

♦ Three massive, open worlds to play in.
♦ Lots of weapon and item stashes, if you know where to look.
♦ The most powerful enemies are only released onto the map after certain side-quests; no super-mutants when you only have a 9mm pistol.
♦ Improved A-Life simulation over Shadow of Chernobyl means a more organic, more lively Zone.
♦ Two join-able factions, each with their own special perks and drawbacks.


♥ And what you don't like about the game, you can mod, change, or remove entirely.[stalker.filefront.com]

reviewText:
Game so fun you have to beat it more than once.
Massive fan base that makes countless fun mods that include: Improved Graphics, Textures, animations, sound effects, new maps, monsters, items, weapons and the implement of online play.
Story: you are an undercover military officer investigating the disappearance of multiple helicopters you are disguised as a stalker with just two weeks supply.
The game drops you in a very difficult environment supply, trade and combat skills are key to survival, it may be very important sometimes to scout your area and must be careful when traveling at night so you don’t stumble upon mutated beast or radiated anomalies. High risk high reward is always a fun aspect for a game, this one shares that aspect when collecting artifacts in anomaly areas or when collecting loot during faction battles, before someone else does, while trying to not to become another by standard as bullets fly over your head.
This game is one of my favorites it’s a must buy for any Survival game fan that enjoys challenges in beautiful landscapes of horror

Pros
sound's from enviromental and gun sound
MODS (GET MISERY MOD)
Open world
Animations
Multiple ending's
item's have nice-quality picture's
GOOD STORY

Cons

reviewText: S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat is a fine example of what every open world survival horror game should be.\n\nLike its predecessors, Clear Sky and Shadow of Chernobyl, Call of Pripyat is set in a very warped exclusion zone.  Compared to the previous entries in GSC's fabulous series, it is the most stable by far, most graphically appealing, and perhaps the scariest.  The AI is superb.  Beyond superb.  I remember reading somewhere that in Shadow of Chernobyl, they had to tone the AI down to make the game playable.  In its original state, an npc could have easily beaten the game itself without player influence.  It was that good.  And it still is amazing.  GSC managed to take probably the best AI model I've seen and place it in the scariest, darkest, and outlandish things imaginable(and unimaginable for that matter).  When placed into monsters that make villains like Chris Walker and SPC-106 seem like drinking buddies, it puts you into ITS ballpark.  In S.T.A.L.K.E.R., you don't get to smirk at stupid decisions by bandits or monsters.  In fact, I've been outsmarted by the AI.  And that doesn't happen often.  The AI isn't supposed to outsmart the player in video games.  YOU'RE supposed to outsmart IT.  GSC essentially threw that to the wind.  I'll give an example.  In one of the quests, you have to hunt down a creature called a Bloodsucker.  Which is already a name to run away from really fast.  So I packed up my AK, a few bottles of Vodka, a few first aid kits, some bandages, and headed out.  Aside from distant gunshots and screams that you just can't mistake for anything besides a human being torn apart, it was a pleasant enough day.  I reach the hunting spot.  Now, Bloodsuckers can turn invisible.  The standard way to deal with them is to get them to chase you in a straight line, then flip around and unload assault rifle fire in their faces.  The bloodsucker however decided to run away from ME.  So I chased after it and it led me on a wild goose chase around the map until we reached the swamps again.  Guess what had happened while we were gone.  Its friends had formed an ambush, while the first creature tired me out and lured me back to give them all an easy kill.  And that was the AI's doing.  No scripting, no cutscene, no quicktime event.  It did that all on its own.  And that's only one of the nightmares you will encounter in this game.  Most horror games scare you by giving you no defenses or weapons.  You're only choice is to hide or run.  In this, you have plenty of weapons.  And I still get scared out of my wits while I play this.  Because in GSC's rendering of Chernobyl, all the weapons in the world aren't going to give you an advantage.  Overall it has a solid storyline, believable characters, and fun sidequests.  So in short, it's probably one of the best games I've ever played.  And if you ever start to get bored of the bounty of content in Call of Pripyat, the amount of player made mods will take care of that.  To make a long story short, this game is worth EVERY. SINGLE. PENNY.  Of course, if you don't like games where you're not a god, where the world isn't at your mercy, don't buy this.  Because in S.T.A.L.K.E.R, you aren't god.  You're mortal just like everyone else.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ranks easily in one of my favorite games of all time. It's an unstable, bug-laden, often-mistranslated with cheating AI piece of game, but god does it do something good.

The ambience, the stress, the setting, the mechanics... Everything that makes an open-world survival game great, way before the recent survival craze on steam. The game is hard as balls by concept, and would have it no other way.

If it reminds you of the Metro series, well, there's a good reason: much of the same people who worked for GSC Game World fo the Stalker series went to do Metro for 4A games. In a sad turn of events, GSC Game World screwed over its employees, and has basically died since this game has come out, so we might never see a S.T.A.L.K.E.R. game again.

Call of Pripyat is arguably the best game in the series due to it relative stability and more mature gameplay mechanics, where Shadow of Chernobyl feels rough around the edges and Clear Sky is just instable and buggy as balls. The main character story was more interesting in Shadow, was utterly uninteresting in Clear Sky, and is mildly interesting this time around in CoP due to a few other characters,,,

You like FPSes, survival games, getting out of here stalker, open-world games, russians swearing, looking at X-Ray engine crash dumps, and crouching in radioactive mud because you're being sniped at midnight by bandits? Buy this game. Now,

reviewText:
I love Call of Pripyat.

I am one of the greatest Stalkers in the zone, and this is my favorite of the original trilogy, simply because it offers more tweaks than Shadow of Chernobyl, and isn't a broken, megalomaniacal, unfinished mess like Clear Sky.

Many fans of STALKER still like Shadow of Chernobyl the most, and while SoC has some great qualities when compared to Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat, CoP simply offers a fun weapon and armor customization, a better and less buggy gameplay, and the Zone remained as immersive as ever.

Unlike Shadow of Chernobyl and Clear Sky, which have a lot of different locations, Call of Pripyat only has 3 locations, which are however very dynamic in cosmetical way, and way, way bigger than any location in SoC or CS - and it worked.

Call of Pripyat managed everything that Clear Sky failed at, literally everything. While the story isn't ground breaking, unlike Clear Sky, or Shadow of Chernobyl at times, it isn't pretencious. The story's very simple: You are a covert military agent infiltrated in the zone as a lone Stalker, who is sent to find out the cause of mysterious crashes of multiple military Mi-24 choppers, and save the eventual survivors, if any. The ending has a loose end, because then-cancelled Stalker 2 project, should have a story that continues from the CoP ending.

If you're a fan of STALKER franchise, you need to finish CoP before Stalker 2 releases, hopefully.

reviewText:
So anyway, My last review of my game was crap, so lets try again.

The game I love is still in here, but this and Clear Sky were weaker compared to SHoC. The story is weaker, (I usually never explain the plot because I don't want to spoil plots) the Gamplay however is much stronger and more better. The maps are much bigger but 3 total Areas? The Upgrades actually assist in gameplay, the Characters are unique and likable, however the AI is a mixed bag, Dialogue is well written but having only like, 5 Voice actors over at GSC annoys me. Very glitchy but you can mod it to what ever degree you want. Stashes no longer require pressing the e key over everything that resembles a corpse. But the Main problem of this game is that it is way too easy. Stick the difficulty up to Veteran or Master if you want a challenge. Your health regenerates very quickly, Money, ammo, and items are easier to obtain, and bullets are so ♥♥♥♥-weak to you but your bullets are rockets to the enemy.

Mod this game to whatever complaint you have, and you will have a more solid game.

7.1/10

reviewText:
As a franchise, GSC Game World's Stalker has come a long way. That the original Shadow of Chernobyl was actually completed and released to the public at all after a seemingly endless string of delays was a bit of a surprise. Sure, it was rough around the edges, but no other game out there offered such an intoxicating mix of horror and bleak beauty like Stalker and the irradiated wastes of its setting. While the follow-up prequel, Clear Sky, was a bit of a disappointment in how it trimmed out a bunch of elements that helped Stalker stand out, Call of Pripyat ditches a lot of the changes made and returns to the series' roots. It's not quite the revelatory experience Shadow of Chernobyl was, but it hits all the right notes for fans of the original and anyone else who values mood in their games and finds entertainment in being scared out of their socks. It also, thankfully, isn't nearly as buggy.

To get the timeline all straightened out, Call of Pripyat is the second title to follow Shadow of Chernobyl and takes place after the events of the first. The game is set in the Zone, a tract of land surrounding the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in which all life has been corrupted and twisted into hideous and deadly forms. Frightening and powerful creatures dwell in isolated underground testing labs and caverns, the landscape is full of dangerous traps that spout fire from the ground and trigger damaging windstorms, and every once in a while an emission blasts across the land wiping out anything silly enough to neglect shelter. Despite the fact that this land sounds entirely inhospitable, it draws fortune seekers in search of curios called artifacts that tend to spawn right in the middle of the anomalous traps. As a result, groups of these stalkers bunch together in whatever safe areas they can find, such as in rusted husks of beached ships, abandoned train stations, and the crumbling remains of Pripyat. The mysterious circumstances surrounding the propagation and sustainment of the Zone have also created several subgroups within the area, including factions that want to wipe it off the planet entirely and those that think its uniqueness alone justifies a need to preserve it.

In this game you play as Alex Degtyarev, a new character and part of a military mission to discover what happened to a number of helicopters sent into The Zone following the climactic events of the first title. Everyone was curious as to what kind of power beat at the setting's center, and after watching Call of Pripyat's opening cutscene it's clear the military didn't have a lot of success finding an answer. As you comb the grounds in search of the damaged military vehicles and their crew members, you'll pass through three large areas comprised of toxic marshes, desiccated fields, decaying industrial facilities and urban wastes, all of which have their own set of side quests and feature plenty of scares and entertaining challenges.

The game is structured like a role-playing title, with primary missions and quest rewards and a trading system where you'll repair guns, buy ammunition and medical supplies, wrap cuts with bandages, and upgrade your gear the further you go. There's no leveling or experience point systems, however, so the power of your character is more directly determined by the kinds of equipment you're carrying around. Like Shadow of Chernobyl, when you start out, you're going to be incredibly vulnerable to the dangers present in the Zone. You'll also be poor. Talking to NPCs, taking on quests, and hunting down and trading artifacts for cash are your best options for upgrades, which in Call of Pripyat is a more interesting process than in the original.

That's because the modification system built into Clear Sky has been imported here, meaning if you talk to specific NPCs and give them what they want, they'll offer services that can do things like upgrade the reliability of your weapon, improve its accuracy, or boost the defensive parameters of your armor. Even by implementing these upgrades, you'll still need to keep an eye on your gear's condition. Call of Pripyat is a game where a sense of realism is crucial to the overall tone of the world, and as such that means your armor can break down and weapons degrade with use. Eventually, guns you've ignored will deteriorate and start to jam with such frequency that there's no point in using them anymore. You'll also need to monitor radiation levels and bring scraps of food on your journey to keep Alex in fighting shape, since it really doesn't take very long for a skittering mutant to claw the life from you.

Though you do still interact with Duty and Freedom factions in the game, the flimsy faction balance system from Clear Sky has been tossed out for Call of Pripyat. The result is a more natural feel to the interplay of AI systems across the Zone. You'll see wandering bands of humans get into some large-scale fights against ravenous packs of mutated dogs and hulking boar creatures. You'll hear this combat in the distance and get the sense that this world is alive and chaotic and exists independently of your actions, which reinforces the elements of realism built into the game's weapon and armor systems and the general vulnerability of your character as you scamper from firefight to firefight.

Guns in Stalker are not incredibly accurate, something that holds true of your weapons and those of your humanoid opponents. Bullets spray everywhere during a fight, encouraging you to crouch down behind cover and fire in quick bursts. It means you'll need to pay attention every time you go to shoot. If you panic and try to fire from the hip while on the move, you're going to get punctured and shredded in seconds. You need to be surgically precise, even after you've purchased upgrades, if you want to stay alive while out on your own. It adds to the authentic feel of the world that by using each weapon, you'll notice a difference in feel almost immediately. The variation between each firearm contributes to a greater sense of growing power and progression as you come across better equipment, keeping you motivated on your journey toward the Zone's secrets.

If you're not questing, you'll find this world interesting enough to make simply wandering around to see the sights and searching for the occasional artifact entertaining. The windswept slopes and unsetting, icy soundtrack never let you relax, building a tension that keeps your attention glued to the events onsceen even if there's nothing happening except for wind swishing through tall grass. It's the threat of action that hooks you and draws you forward, since you never know if something like a cloaked bloodsucker or loping snork is waiting for you behind the next rise as rainstorms wash across the fields and day turns to night. It's an environment built with such clarity of vision, that feels so alien and hostile that simply managing to survive a journey from one location to the next feels like an accomplishment, a feeling amplified greatly when you manage to actually uncover a cool new item or pocket of bizarre activity.

Unfortunately, there are elements that eat away at the atmosphere of the world, and those are the voice acting, quest text and delivery. The English voice acting in the game is from time to time decent, but frequently irritatingly overenthusiastic. I'm not looking to hear Hey
date: bro!" screamed with the cadence of someone who just slammed a line of Jager bombs after I nearly lost my head in a snork nest. A lot of text is also copy and pasted between conversation trees with non-essential NPCs
hoursPlayed: and the overall delivery of the story is very straightforward. So
voteText: if you want to learn all you can about the zone
helpfulPercent: it means digging through a lot of limp text in chat boxes.\n\n10/10"

reviewText: Right from the get-go, it should be said that this is a different game from Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl. In Shadow of Chernobyl (SoC), the entire game had a sense of mystery about it, a kind of unanswered questions vibe. It was a question of surviving the endless horrors of the Zone, of loud rain and calamitous thunder at night, and of breathtaking sunrises in the morning, as one gazes out at the brooding wilderness. It also encompassed a sense of massive and epic scale, as the player struggles for mere survival while the Monolith elite jealously guard the entrance to the Sarcophagus while the Ukrainian Military pours in all their best fighters, special forces armed to the teeth and guarded from above by a fleet of Mi-24 Hinds, to force their way through. Unsettling screams and distant gunfire at night, beautiful blood-red sunrises in the barren hills near the Army Warehouses, the haunting soundtrack of Cordon filling one's ears as stalkers wander aimlessly through the irradiated meadows, vengeance, melancholy, fear, and grandeur. THAT is the essence of SoC. Call of Pripyat gives off a different atmosphere. From the moment the player spawns, as he gazes out over the beautifully rendered swamps of Zaton, one gets the sense of opportunity. The Zone has been tamed, and there's money to be made here. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it does somewhat lessen the more emotional experience of SoC. Soundtrack was good. Weapons were unique and fun each in their own way, with customization available for most (they weakened my dear Ots-14! Waaaaaaaaaaaaaah!). Armor was plentiful, with many choices to pick (although no Merc Suit or Skat 9M). Characters were well-rounded, combat worked like a charm, the missions were sometimes tedious but on the whole more varied than the original game. I also particularly enjoyed the Factional Strife which one could get involved in in Call of Pripyat. I only wish that SoC had it. Playing the Loners and Bandits off on one another, or eschewing both in favor of the shadowy information dealer Owl makes the game much more lively, with some high-stakes plays to heighten the standing of your favoured faction. It is a pity one could not join the Mercenaries under Hatchet (what a swell guy!). I also liked the very idea of working with a fellow whose trade is the bartering of information (a valuable commodity in a place such as this!). I enjoyed the fact that some of these missions helped give one a sense of the scope of the Mercenary activities in the Zone, for they are without a doubt the most secretive faction.  Apparently they have some influential friends/allies. On the downside, I did not enjoy the fact that each weapon needed to be repaired before selling- this made the game much more difficult, especially since one needed to buy certain items in order to progress in the game. On the whole a fantastic game- not quite SoC, but worthy in its' own right.\n9.9/10

reviewText:
As a franchise, GSC Game World's Stalker has come a long way. That the original Shadow of Chernobyl was actually completed and released to the public at all after a seemingly endless string of delays was a bit of a surprise. Sure, it was rough around the edges, but no other game out there offered such an intoxicating mix of horror and bleak beauty like Stalker and the irradiated wastes of its setting. While the follow-up prequel, Clear Sky, was a bit of a disappointment in how it trimmed out a bunch of elements that helped Stalker stand out, Call of Pripyat ditches a lot of the changes made and returns to the series' roots. It's not quite the revelatory experience Shadow of Chernobyl was, but it hits all the right notes for fans of the original and anyone else who values mood in their games and finds entertainment in being scared out of their socks. It also, thankfully, isn't nearly as buggy.

To get the timeline all straightened out, Call of Pripyat is the second title to follow Shadow of Chernobyl and takes place after the events of the first. The game is set in the Zone, a tract of land surrounding the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in which all life has been corrupted and twisted into hideous and deadly forms. Frightening and powerful creatures dwell in isolated underground testing labs and caverns, the landscape is full of dangerous traps that spout fire from the ground and trigger damaging windstorms, and every once in a while an emission blasts across the land wiping out anything silly enough to neglect shelter. Despite the fact that this land sounds entirely inhospitable, it draws fortune seekers in search of curios called artifacts that tend to spawn right in the middle of the anomalous traps. As a result, groups of these stalkers bunch together in whatever safe areas they can find, such as in rusted husks of beached ships, abandoned train stations, and the crumbling remains of Pripyat. The mysterious circumstances surrounding the propagation and sustainment of the Zone have also created several subgroups within the area, including factions that want to wipe it off the planet entirely and those that think its uniqueness alone justifies a need to preserve it.

In this game you play as Alex Degtyarev, a new character and part of a military mission to discover what happened to a number of helicopters sent into The Zone following the climactic events of the first title. Everyone was curious as to what kind of power beat at the setting's center, and after watching Call of Pripyat's opening cutscene it's clear the military didn't have a lot of success finding an answer. As you comb the grounds in search of the damaged military vehicles and their crew members, you'll pass through three large areas comprised of toxic marshes, desiccated fields, decaying industrial facilities and urban wastes, all of which have their own set of side quests and feature plenty of scares and entertaining challenges.

The game is structured like a role-playing title, with primary missions and quest rewards and a trading system where you'll repair guns, buy ammunition and medical supplies, wrap cuts with bandages, and upgrade your gear the further you go. There's no leveling or experience point systems, however, so the power of your character is more directly determined by the kinds of equipment you're carrying around. Like Shadow of Chernobyl, when you start out, you're going to be incredibly vulnerable to the dangers present in the Zone. You'll also be poor. Talking to NPCs, taking on quests, and hunting down and trading artifacts for cash are your best options for upgrades, which in Call of Pripyat is a more interesting process than in the original.

That's because the modification system built into Clear Sky has been imported here, meaning if you talk to specific NPCs and give them what they want, they'll offer services that can do things like upgrade the reliability of your weapon, improve its accuracy, or boost the defensive parameters of your armor. Even by implementing these upgrades, you'll still need to keep an eye on your gear's condition. Call of Pripyat is a game where a sense of realism is crucial to the overall tone of the world, and as such that means your armor can break down and weapons degrade with use. Eventually, guns you've ignored will deteriorate and start to jam with such frequency that there's no point in using them anymore. You'll also need to monitor radiation levels and bring scraps of food on your journey to keep Alex in fighting shape, since it really doesn't take very long for a skittering mutant to claw the life from you.

Though you do still interact with Duty and Freedom factions in the game, the flimsy faction balance system from Clear Sky has been tossed out for Call of Pripyat. The result is a more natural feel to the interplay of AI systems across the Zone. You'll see wandering bands of humans get into some large-scale fights against ravenous packs of mutated dogs and hulking boar creatures. You'll hear this combat in the distance and get the sense that this world is alive and chaotic and exists independently of your actions, which reinforces the elements of realism built into the game's weapon and armor systems and the general vulnerability of your character as you scamper from firefight to firefight.

Guns in Stalker are not incredibly accurate, something that holds true of your weapons and those of your humanoid opponents. Bullets spray everywhere during a fight, encouraging you to crouch down behind cover and fire in quick bursts. It means you'll need to pay attention every time you go to shoot. If you panic and try to fire from the hip while on the move, you're going to get punctured and shredded in seconds. You need to be surgically precise, even after you've purchased upgrades, if you want to stay alive while out on your own. It adds to the authentic feel of the world that by using each weapon, you'll notice a difference in feel almost immediately. The variation between each firearm contributes to a greater sense of growing power and progression as you come across better equipment, keeping you motivated on your journey toward the Zone's secrets.

If you're not questing, you'll find this world interesting enough to make simply wandering around to see the sights and searching for the occasional artifact entertaining. The windswept slopes and unsetting, icy soundtrack never let you relax, building a tension that keeps your attention glued to the events onsceen even if there's nothing happening except for wind swishing through tall grass. It's the threat of action that hooks you and draws you forward, since you never know if something like a cloaked bloodsucker or loping snork is waiting for you behind the next rise as rainstorms wash across the fields and day turns to night. It's an environment built with such clarity of vision, that feels so alien and hostile that simply managing to survive a journey from one location to the next feels like an accomplishment, a feeling amplified greatly when you manage to actually uncover a cool new item or pocket of bizarre activity.

Unfortunately, there are elements that eat away at the atmosphere of the world, and those are the voice acting, quest text and delivery. The English voice acting in the game is from time to time decent, but frequently irritatingly overenthusiastic. I'm not looking to hear Hey
date: bro!" screamed with the cadence of someone who just slammed a line of Jager bombs after I nearly lost my head in a snork nest. A lot of text is also copy and pasted between conversation trees with non-essential NPCs

reviewText: This game is great! Its pretty much Fallout in Russia from what I gathered. However, a true man doth not have felt difficulty until doth had played MISERY. This conversion for CoP is incredibly difficult and is not for the weak. reviewText:
Between the mods, the community (or crazies) that live and breath this game, and my own immutable curiousity of this title, I quickly realized that this was a solid purchase. I cant compare it to anything because nothing comes to mind. It feeels like a predecessor to Metro but I think that is only because they are both Russian. So thats not fair. But its precisely because it cant be easily grouped in with other games that you should buy it.

Here are the mistakes I made that you should avoid. Do not immediately mod the game. It will be tempting. The All-In-One mod pack with AtmosFear 3 and Absolute Nature are just great. But without playing it vanilla first then you cant fully appreciate the mods. Dont spend your time making numerous saves because you arent sure what to sell and what to keep. Just go with it. Trust your gut. Move on. The game will be more fun. Also, pay attention to what people ssay. I lost focused during a few conversations fairly early on and I think I sold something that I needed to progress. Maybe I didnt. But I was stuck...somehow. And it was all because I got distracted by my GF yelling about something in the other room. It turned out to be a boy and now we are all very happy. I just wish she wouldnt distract me when Im trying to concentrate wheen its something she is perfectly capable of handling herself.

The game is a classic. If you dont own it, get it. If you refuse to buy it get medicated and do not send me a friend request, ever.

10/10 - would ignore a living room birth again

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a mystery to me. There are SO MANY problems with it, and yet I still enjoyed playing it. Is it a great game? NO. But is it a good game? MAYBE.
I have seen other reviews claim CoP is a better, more challening Fallout, but this is simply not true.

VISUALS
Everything in this game is repetitive and ugly. I have seen multiple reviews, even professional ones, claim that the visuals in this game are great, and I absolutely do not see why! I am not talking about graphics, which are so obviously below standard it's not even worth criticism. No, I mean atmosphere and appearance. First, every area of the game has the same open fields, short hills, boring trees, bushes, and grass. There is nothing in the natural scene that is beautiful or scary (I even installed Atmosfear, which is a beautification mod). Every building is square and industrial, filled with empty, useless rooms. This, far and above, is awful to look at. CoP is FILLED with identical buildings!

Second, the oft-cited tense and scary atmosphere is present, albeit rarely. Truly scary or tense moments are governed by the RNG and therefore often missing. One of the strengths" of this game
recommended: is how independent the world is. Monsters and NPCs will spawn semi-randomly and often collide with the player and each other. However
hoursPlayed: this also means that the chances a creature will appear in empty building #127 that you exploring is actually very rare. Often I navigated a creepy abandoned factory (they're all factories
voteText: remember?) at night
helpfulPercent: with only a flashlight to guide me
votesHelpful: all the while expecting some monstrosity to come at me
votesTotal: and NOTHING HAPPENED. I would find my loot
votesFunny: and go back to the safe zone
commentsCount: yet again. Boring. The best creepy moments

were the scripted ones at the end of the game! (which were few)

COMBAT
The second thing this game is known for is the FPS combat. One positive element of the game is that almost any enemy can kill you all by itself. Supposedly
column17: this means you have to be very cautious in any combat situation and fight tactically. In reality
column18: combat is the simplest rinse-and-repeat affair I have seen in many other games. Human enemies are a great example. If you are within firing range they WILL hit you (apparently every fool in the zone is an expert marksman) and kill you in a few shots. So
column19: what is the strategy to defeat them? Easy: 1) hide behind cover
column21: 3) consume a medkit to recover any damage. THAT'S IT. These three steps are pretty much the same for every enemy in the game
column22: except for one that can go invisible (which is actually EASIER to kill). Headshots do very high damage (as they should in any serious FPS)
column23: but the moronic AI just stands there and shoots like a British Redcoat
column24: so there is nothing stopping you from dropping enemies like flies. I have put hundreds of hours into TF2
column25: so a headshot on a non-human player is like shooting fish in a barrel for me. I have literally stood in an open field
column27: and killed four human attackers (NOT zombies) all firing at me without dying. Then
column28:
I just popped a couple medkits and waltzed away.

What good is the amazing targeting scope on my sniper rifle when I already killed the 12 enemy fighters in the apartment building BEFORE I got it!? This is even worse with the armor. The best armor in the game does not allow you to run while wearing it until you have the final tier upgrade for it. Once again
column59:
this armor is completely uselss for 90% of the game.

MAP LEVELS
The final frustrating element of this game is the map itself. So many players completely overlook that this game is really just a walking simulator. There is NO transportation or fast travel in this game. YOU. WALK. EVERYWHERE. Or more accurately
column69: everywhere! You spend SO MUCH time walking! It's enfuriating. This game is not like Fallout/Skyrim where interesting events happen to you while you travel. At best you may happen upon some humans fending off a mutant attack. Honestly
column70: the best strategy here is just to watch
column71: because usually the mutants kill the humans
column72: and you can loot their bodies. Otherwise
column73: there is no reason to waste hours walking. To make matters worse
column74: because your primary source of money in the game are special items called artifacts that are located in the far corners of each map and that respawn at random every few days
column75: you will do A LOT of backtracking.\n\nFurthermore
column76: the map is divided into three levels that you can only travel between by use of a guide. This "guide" is basically fast travel
column79: and then you are instantly transported to the next area. You CANNOT access the other areas of the game on foot. You must PAY a guide to take you EVERY time you want to change levels (which is a lot). The reason for this is so obvious: the developers needed to separate all of the assets in the game so it wouldn't completely overload our computers. Finally
column80: the third level of the game
column81: which is really your primary goal
column82: is both small and extremely short. What should be a climactic final level
column83:
is over in a handful of quests.


Honestly
column84: there are so many other things I could complain about
column85: but I still choose to recommend this game because you can pick it up for nearly nothing during a sale. This game barely registers in the positive for me at a 6/10
column86: but if you have a couple extra bucks come the next big sale
column87: you may want to give it a try just to see what all the fuss is about."

The final frustrating element of this game is the map itself. So many players completely overlook that this game is really just a walking simulator. There is NO transportation or fast travel in this game. YOU. WALK. EVERYWHERE. Or more accurately
column69: everywhere! You spend SO MUCH time walking! It's enfuriating. This game is not like Fallout/Skyrim where interesting events happen to you while you travel. At best you may happen upon some humans fending off a mutant attack. Honestly
column70: the best strategy here is just to watch
column71: because usually the mutants kill the humans
column72: and you can loot their bodies. Otherwise
column73: there is no reason to waste hours walking. To make matters worse
column74: because your primary source of money in the game are special items called artifacts that are located in the far corners of each map and that respawn at random every few days
column75: you will do A LOT of backtracking.\n\nFurthermore
column76: the map is divided into three levels that you can only travel between by use of a guide. This "guide" is basically fast travel
column79: and then you are instantly transported to the next area. You CANNOT access the other areas of the game on foot. You must PAY a guide to take you EVERY time you want to change levels (which is a lot). The reason for this is so obvious: the developers needed to separate all of the assets in the game so it wouldn't completely overload our computers. Finally
column80: the third level of the game
column81: which is really your primary goal
column82: is both small and extremely short. What should be a climactic final level
column83:
is over in a handful of quests.


Honestly
column84: there are so many other things I could complain about
column85: but I still choose to recommend this game because you can pick it up for nearly nothing during a sale. This game barely registers in the positive for me at a 6/10
column86: but if you have a couple extra bucks come the next big sale
column87: you may want to give it a try just to see what all the fuss is about."

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a brilliant game that bends atmoshpere with brilliant gameplay.

The game does not hand-hold you and straight from the get go you are dropped on a hill with a few markers showing the main story objectives. You only have a few supplies and if you go straight to the objectives you will likely find yourself having your body drained by a bloodsucker. How do you get better equipment? by exploring the world doing jobs for people, hunting mutants, hunting bandits or even becoming a bandit.

You are free to chase money for better equipment as much as you like, there is no timer or voice on a radio shouting for you to get to checkpoint alpha and shoot your quota of terrorists. Nope, you have all the time in the world to have fun and get absorbed into the world.

A great inventory system means that you will always find yourself wondering which weapons you should take with you and how much ammo. The health system is also great with the depth of protection different armors adding more to it. You have bullet penetration and blunt force protection, first effects how easily you will bleed and the other how much health you lose when hit. There are also plenty of other protections provided from armor like radiation, acid, electrical  and a thermal. All the different damages that can effect your character add more to the medical system as different drugs and medpacks have different buffs and values. So before heading out you may have to decide whether or not to sell that scientic medpack for more ammo or keep it for an emergency.

The artifact system mixes in well with the gameplay as there is an array of different artifacts with some having very high values but also very usefull buffs. The way to get these artifacts is eithe to get lucky when looting a body or braving one of the many dangerous anomalies. The better and higher value artifacts will rarely turn up and only if you explore the more dangerous anomalies. Then when you do find one will you keep it to gain an additional 13Kg or sell it to able to afford that fancy exo-skeleton armor.

When all this is put into practice the system performs very well with both mutants and humans. When fighting humans the AI is good enough that stealth is viable but hard, and that when ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan the combat is tough but enjoyable. Ths is not a run and gun game and if you try to charge head first you will quickly find it laying a few feet away from the bloody stump that is now your neck. The combat requires you to be able to think at least a little tactically as you have no regenerating health and limited medical supplies. The enemies wil even look towards where they last saw you and occasionaly try to flush you out with grenades, this enables you to slip out of sight and try and get a flank on them. At the end of a fight you feel like you deserved the victory because you worked for it, and then you get the satisfaction of rooting through the pockets of your dead enemies.

The AI also performs well when your fighting mutants. Dogs will swarm you in packs and if one is injured it will pull away to lick its wounds while two more dogs charge you. Bloodsuckers will sneak behind you and try to drain you of your blood, and there is very little more nerve wracking than hearing their cloaking sound and watching for their telltale shimmer. The AI performs well with the player having to change their playstyle to match what type of enemy they are fighting.

All in all S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a great addition to the series with superb gameplay melded into a well crafted world which you can truely be absorbed into. 10/10 brilliant game and totally recommend playing it.


BONUS ADDITION- Beyond the original vanilla game there are a multitude of brilliant mods for it, ranging from simple graphics improvements to complete overhauls of the game. The community is brilliant and the modmakers are true fans of the game and this shows in some of the mods made for it. Highly recommend MISERY mod, which is a complete overhaul that adds a whole ♥♥♥♥-ton of depth with more weapons, drugs, armors, ammo, upgrades and even changes the medical system and AI to be even more realistic. If i had to give MISERY a score it would have to 11/10

reviewText:
The STALKER* games are amazing. There is so much atmosphere. Imagine you are walking alone on a rainy night. Something is following you but you can't quite see it. You can sometimes hear it over the thunder and rain. Occasionally when there's lightening you see a silhouette on the ridge above you. You can't tell what it is. And you don't know if you have the firepower to kill it. So you keep moving towards your base. Glancing over your shoulder. Waiting for an attack that might not come. It's awesome.

The weapons are great and the shooting mechanic feels incredible. It has a good story with many interesting locations. Highly recommended.

*Shadow Over Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat are amazing. STALKER Clear Skies is just pretty good.

reviewText:
The first game, Shadow of Chernobyl, was one of the best games I've ever played. Clear Sky, the second installment to the franchise and a prequel to the first game, was an overwhelming disappointment. I was skeptical when coming to Call of Pripyat, but I can say without a doubt in my mind, that this is one of the greatest video games of all time.

STORY
Where Clear Sky faltered with a dull story, Call of Pripyat brings forth a new, compelling, and interesting story that spans throughout untold countless hours of gameplay. For the first time, optional missions and side quests have their own stories, ranking among my favourites in RPGs. Memorable missions such as sneaking through a lair of sleeping Bloodsuckers, joining a team of hunters to kill a massive Chimera, overseeing a trade of information between enemy factions and then sniping them from a distance, and discovering the secrets hidden throughout the Pripyat area make the side missions a wonder to play through. While the central story isn't as deep and strong as the first game, it can be expanded upon through hundreds of optional missions which alone give the game far more replayability. A cast of new and surprisingly memorable characters filters into the game, all with their own distinctive and unique personality traits. For the first time, we finally get to go deeper into the city of Pripyat, to explore the old ruins of the world's biggest ghost town.

GAMEPLAY
Strong gunplay against intelligent enemy fighters and nightmarish mutants with a set of their own unique attacks ranks Call of Pripyat among some of the best FPS games I've ever played. Weapons will jam after prolonged use and wear, enemies will relentlessly and savagely attack you, flanking, taking cover, reacting in new and dynamic ways, even traveling around the world and engaging in fights among themselves. Suits and weapons can be seamlessly upgraded through assisting characters. This is undoubtedly the strongest of the series.

GRAPHICS
Much like Clear Sky, the visuals just seem to fall flat. They're beautiful, most certainly, but there's simply little to no immersion like the first game. While there are haunting environments and surreal moments when you reach the dead city, I simply didn't get the same feelings that sparked through me as I assaulted the Brain Scorcher, fought waves of charging mutants, and battled my way inside the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Shadow of Chernobyl. Visually, the game does look quite good, though I am sorey disappointed to see that the beautifully detailed and ominous cutscenes present in the first two games are suddenly and without warning absent from Call of Pripyat. The jerky, awkward in-game cutscenes are laughable at best, and the slideshow cutscenes in the beginning and end of the game are groan inducing and all around pitiful attempts to recreate the CGI of the first to games. Nonetheless, graphically the game is stellar, and even running at medium settings the game still looks great.

MULTIPLAYER
Unfortunately, I have never seen more than one other person playing the multiplayer of this game, and therefore cannot make a full review on that particular portion. However, from what I've tested, the game modes look fun, gameplay is very much intact, and the new maps look interesting and well-detailed. If you have a few friends who want to play, a private lobby for this game looks like it could be unending fun.

VERDICT
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a well polished, fun, entertaining, and overall incredible game. It took me nearly 17 hours to complete the main story, and I still haven't even scratched the surface of the overall package with the wealth of optional missions and exploration available to the player. While the story may not stack up to the mystery and horror of Shadow of Chernobyl, and while the survival/horror gameplay present in the first game is still quite lackluster, Call of Pripyat proves itself to be a fantastic experience. Had I not owned a PC of my own at the time of my playthrough of this game, I would have sold all of my consoles soley to play Call of Pripyat. A strong modding community keeps the game fresh and exciting, and I highly suggest that before playing, everyone install the S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat COMPLETE mod, as it enhances the visuals and adds a few new and fun mechanics that blend seamlessly with the central game. I didn't think anything could beat the first game, but this alone proves me wrong. The only true complaints I have are minor and do not derive from the full package. This is a game that I will be playing for years to come and still will find it new and fascinating each and every time I play. This is money well spent and perhaps one of the greatest video games ever made. With that said, the final verdict of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat, is an astounding 10/10. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'll be trying to figure out how to kill all of these mutants and keep the bandits off my back.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat is the third game in the outstanding S.T.A.L.K.E.R series, and the most recently released and most recent in the in-game chronology. You play as USS Special Agent Major Degtyarev, sent to investigate the failure of a airborne assault into the center of the Zone. Eventually, you will be give free-reign over 3 large and well-made overworlds:Zaton, the start;Yanov, the area surrounding the Jupiter plant; and Pripyat, the city closest to the CNPP.

PROS

+Atmosphere rarely fails to scare or instill a sense of awe in you.
+Many side missions, random events, and emissions to keep you on your toes.
+Varied and effective (or ineffective) types of weapons and armor
+Many types of mutants, ranging from mutated dogs to massive mutated humans who have become little more than a head and legs.
+The natural enviroment is teeming with radiation and 'anomalies', which can burn you with fire, melt you with acid, make your head explode, and send you flying, amongst others
+Few bugs, compared to Clear Sky
+Active and varied modding community, home to one of the best mods I've ever played: MISERY

CONS

-Its age often causes technical problems, leading to either lag or inoperabillity
-Dated vanilla graphics and sound
-Gunplay is unforgiving and disorientating to new players.
-Little hope of a sequel (unless the newly reformed GSC is working on one without my knowladge.)
-Possible(?) lack of support for some headphones; I've had issues getting mine to work correctly occasionally.

OVERALL

Audio-7/10

Visuals-8/10

Gameplay-10/10

Multiplayer-0/10 (no longer supported)


S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Call of Pripyat, overall, is an amazing game. No other game has scared me as much as this game has, and it improved upon the best and worst parts of both Clear Sky and Shadow of Chernobyl. The modding community has updated its graphics and sound, added new weapons, mutants, and changed fundamental aspects of it while still keeping it true to its roots. However, it's plagued by constant crashes on some machines, incompatabillity with overlays (possibly including the Steam In-Game Overlay), and the lack of supported multiplayer. However, this game is mostly only single-player, so that barely dents this nearly flawless game.

Final Grade-9/10


NOTE: As I stated, there are many mods for this game. As such, I'll include a short list of the ones I believe that most people will enjoy and appreciate.

|BEGINNER MODS/MODPACKS|

CoP: Complete-a visual overhaul of the vanilla game, adds little else. Perfect for a first playthrough.
AtmosFEAR-A redesign of the weather effects in-game

Most armor and weaponry mods will fall into this catagory


|INTERMEDIARY MODS/MODPACKS|

Some weapon mods will change how weapons work/how often they're found/what condition they will be found in. This will drastically change how the game plays. Such mods will fall into this catagory.

MISERY:Rookie Mode-A subset of the MISERY mod that dials back the difficulty slightly. Good for second or third playthroughs. Download the most updated version of MISERY and simply enable Rookie Mod whenever it gives you the choice.


|ADVANCED MODS/MODPACKS|

MISERY-A complete overhaul of CoP's weapons, armor, mutants, visuals, audio, and weather. Removes many easy ways to gain cash to increase difficulty, and also increases weapon damage significantly, both for you and any and all NPC's. The quintessential S.T.A.L.K.E.R experience.

Most mods that change the main story or mess with integral mechanics fall here


|THE BLACK ROAD|

This subset of the MISERY mod falls in its own catagory due to it's masochistic level of difficulty. Same as the MISERY Mod, except that you start with a flashlight, a knife, no map, no food, no ammo or weapons inside of a compound FILLED with zombies. Simply getting out of the starting area can create levels of frustration far in excess of a large portion of Dark Souls' story mode. The sun also gives you radiation poisoning, meaning you will have to choose between glowing to death, or getting ripped apart by the nocturnal mutants of the Zone. Do not play this unless you have mastered everything there is to know about the MISERY mod and S.T.A.L.K.E.R itself.

reviewText: Excellent game. Far shorter than the original SoC. 3 large areas. Not as challenging as CS/SoC, but still a great experience overall. I put a ton of time just upgrading weapons/armor and finding artifacts. One thing to note: When you finally go to Pripyat, make sure you do not have stuff in your personal stashes. I lost all my weapons/armors that way. It ticked me off so much I just decided to go through to end the game quickly. I did not do faction stuff since in CS that made the game tons harder. I tried to stay as neutral as I could, so I didn't have to deal with bandits/stalkers/freedom/duty. It was enough with the mutants. :P I do intend to repay it only because I know that there is that evil personal stash deletion after arriving in Pripyat. (this really irritated me since I did the way to Pripyat with my silenced-scoped rifle and SEVA armor, I kept myself as light as possible so I could farm loot.. well.. it backfired on me. :/

reviewText:
My alltime favorite game. Also my least favorite game. I love the gameplay, the story, the everything. Hate the gamebreaking bugs, which are basically all the bugs. TL;DR?
It wasn't that long. Oh well, 9.9/10.

-100,000,000,000,000,000,000,000.1 for the game breaking bugs.

reviewText:
S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is GSC Game World's magnum opus. They went out with a bang by making not only the best game in the series but their best game ever.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat is a First-Person Shooter / Role-Playing / Survival Horror game. It's what happens when you take the best elements of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl and S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky, stick them together and add open-world exploration into the mix.

After the slight misstep that was Clear Sky, GSC Game World listened to the fans, did a complete turn in the other direction and went back to what made Shadow of Chernobyl such fun to play.

Call of Pripyat is set after Shadow of Chernobyl. You play as an undercover military agent, Alex Degtyarev. You are sent into the Zone to find out why a party of helicopters, that were advancing into the Zone after the events in Shadow of Chernobyl took place, crashed.

This is without a doubt the most polished game of the series. The game gives you three incredibly huge open areas for you to explore however you want, with lots of side missions to do and things to find. Exploration has a heavier focus now than it did over the last two games.

The A-Life" system
date: artificial life designed to react worldwide to what happens in the Zone
hoursPlayed: monsters will move into places that might have been previously been occupied by humans or other mutants. This makes locations around the Zone a constantly unsafe place to live
voteText:
especially at night.

GSC Game World also brought back the visual and sound indicators as well as the need to eat and drink. You can now also sleep if you want but be sure to eat something before you sleep.

The story is also mush improved over S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky and whilst this game keeps the horror parts pretty short

reviewText:
I felt like my last review was a bit harsh, so I'm putting up another one after playing the game for a few straight hours.

CoP has given me mixed feelings. It's honestly a GOOD game, but gets severely butchered by awful performance. The atmosphere, the lighting, the mods, the horror and survival elements are done well enough to keep me playing for awhile, that's until the stuttering gets worse and worse to the point where it becomes a huge chore to continue, which really sucks because I could play this game forever without the technical flaws. STALKER gives me feelings that I don't get in other games. I'm saddened to leave it behind. I strongly feel that STALKER needs a reboot. I would play the föck out of a new STALKER game running on a beefier engine, like the 4A engine! The extra polish would be well-deserved. I'm deeply sorry to give thumbs down, but CoP goes against what makes a game a game - Stability. Without a stable framerate, how do you apply/develop skills or even stay immersed? Such a shame. Good effort, but better luck next time, future devs. I'm out of here, stalker.

Additional info (in case you haven't said F U!!!" already):
I finished the story once on sheeti pc hardware (dafuq was wrong with me?). I now run a Core i5-4460
hoursPlayed: 120GB SSD and a G-Sync monitor

reviewText:
If ever there was a fantastic FPS that spat in the faces of genre conventions and flew under the radar as it showed what creativity looks like in this era of gaming, itd be the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series.

This series and its developers gave birth to the Metro series. The excellent Atmospheric FPS series that rose from the ashes after the death of GSC and the STALKER series. This series has some of the best atmosphere ever seen in first-person shooters. Metro continued that tradition and arguably has better atmosphere albeit in a smaller space. The only FPS that comes to mind in atmosphere to me at the moment would be The Darkness video game from 2007 by Starbreeze.

Long version with possible spoilers.

STALKER takes place in a fictional modern times where the Chernobyl power plant accident had lasting and terrifying effects on the earth and wildlife around it. Mutants, deadly fauna, radiation pockets, killer anomalies, clashing factions and bandits all exist and contend with each other in this post-apocolyptic slice of Ukraine. The radioactive fallout from the reactor cores exploding left Chernobyl and its outlying towns abandoned by civilians and open to the exploitation factions and mercenaries. The Atmosphere gives a bleak outlook with people dying constantly in gruesome ways from being mauled to drowning in radioactive water or being torn to pieces by a viscious anomally. Mutants roam the contrysides looking for fresh food from anyone or anything. Bandits harass every faction or person they can find and often shoot on sight just to save themselves some trouble. Scientists have mercenaries working to protect them as they fight to keep their research continuing and out of the wrong hands. The military constantly tries to muscle its way in to take control of everything, and is allied with no one but themselves. There are 2 main factions Duty and Freedom. They constantly fight each other for differing beliefs while the military tries to control the zone entirely. Throughout the game you'll get opportunities to support whatever factions you'd like, even the bandits, and with several more factions that i didn't list being in the game, the possibilities are many and varied.

The Atmosphere is stunning and is oozing with detail. The gamplay itself is great, not the pinnacle of first-person shooters but solid across the board and excelling in certain aspects. The gunplay is precise but also has a nice level of upredictability that challenges the player. Often a small encounter with as little as 2 or 3 well armed soldiers can quickly lead to your death if not handled well and without precise shooting. There isn't a massive amount of different guns to be found but each gun will carry distict advantages or disadvantages. All weapons are upgradable and customizable with upgrade trees and attachments, leading to more meaningful weapon statistic differences and each weapon type has at least 2 ammunition types for different enemies. There are many different armor suits to find, some of them come with a helmet attached, some you can choose the helmet or gasmask you want. All the armors and helmets are also upgradeable with upgrade trees that give different bonuses. You can kill a soldier off in the distance whose gun you want and claim it for your own, or you can do missions around the local stronghold or your favorite faction and earn new armor, guns and ammo, some of them faction specific.

The story is pretty good and has many different paths to take. There's many endings and many interesting characters. The game doesn't have much voice acting or at least not in the english version, but the story still holds its own. Its an intersting setting with cool ideas and at the center of it stands The Zone. The big mystery of the entire game. What is The Zone? Is it sentient? Does it control all the creatures that have resulted from the fallout? Does it have psychic abilities? Did it cause all the chaos and damage? Is it afraid of humans? So many questions, so many theories and so many people fighting over ideals and the opportunity to get to the center of the entire incident, The Zone.

Everything about this game is well done and well thought out. The gunplay is solid accross the board. the graphics are great and at the time, were cutting edge. The atmosphere is rivaled only by a select few in the genre. The story is interesting. The setting is unique as is the premise. The RPG elements are great but not overbearing to those who aren't fans of the genre. All in all this game is the best and most refined game of a series of amazing and undervalued games from the 2000-2010 decade. It is a must buy to Metro fans, FPS fans, hardcore gamers and pretty much anyone who enjoys a great atmosphere and an excellent melting pot of awesome mechanics. The game has done its part to earn its loyal fan base and you owe to yourself to at least try it out. Pick up the 1st game, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl, and see where it takes you. I'd bet good money you won't be dissapointed.

Graphics 8.5/10 (9.5 in 2007 when SoC 1st released).
Gameplay 9/10
Story 8.5/10
Atmosphere 10/10

Call of Pripyat gets a 9.5/10 from me.

The entire series gets a 9/10.  [/spoiler]

reviewText: Great game, one of few I consider my favorite games of all time. The game allows for VERY dynamic things to happen and some (maybe most I'm not really sure) have a real life scenario. I missed a target in a mission and failed it, no retries. Although I'm not really sure if it had a real effect on what happened to me it did impress me at the time. Sometimes things just complete themselves when you're not there because the game doesnt really revolve around you. You're just there to enjoy it. I did sure enjoy it too, lots of things to do, dynamic EVERYTHING (varies), very scary and suspensful moments, not being invincible at all, and just having an almost open world (different zones but mostly open). This game and the series is a must play and even if it does get boring or even not that challenging, there are many MANY mods to make it different and even more diverse. This game is overall impressive.

reviewText:
They almost got it right this time around. By far the most playable and enjoyable title in the Stalker trilogy. There are a few of pacing issues and the story just isn't exactly gripping but
they cut down on the random firefights and all out action so you get to actually enjoy the scenery and really take in the morbid atmosphere of the deserted, nuclear wasteland that is the Zone.
Sneaking through some run down garages or factory halls at night with thunderstorms roaring outside has never felt so intense - most likely the closest thing to actually being there.

Game still has a ton of glitches, bugs and errors all around and even modding doesn't fix it all plus the gunplay is just as broken (some say realistic) as in the previous games (thank the Monolith for mechs and weapon upgrades). Still, it is the most userfriendly and probably least quirky of the trilogy - just lacking a bit of the excitement and mysticism of the original, but it excels at everything else.

reviewText:
Great game, great gameplay, amazing story, nice side quests, definitely recommended.

Love how you can farm for artifacts, sell all of them, then spend all the money on vodka.


Mods recommended:

Complete or Arsenal Overhaul 3.1 + Pripyat Reborn, also you can try FOV switcher.

After beating the game with one of those mods above, if you want some serious difficulty and challenge with whole different game, go for Misery.

Though remember that you can't merge AO, Complete or Misery, you can only have one of those installed.

reviewText:
EDIT: Many people say this game cannot run at all on older computers and it has **** AI. No. It has some pretty good AI. And I have ran this game on an old, non-gaming laptop and it runs fine and with no bugs. But F*** Bloodsuckers. No bugs with them, I just hate them.



You slowly walk about in a secret bunker, checking every corner, listening for any sign of life. You suddenly hear something move and turn around and a box goes flying into your face. As you run back looking for a safe bottleneck so that you can see what attacked you. Eventually something lurches from the darkness and starts picking up boxes and barrels with telepathy. You run up and blast it's face into mush. You revel in your triumph before you hear a roar and then your vision goes black.

This game is definitly amazing and even better with the MISERY mod. NOTE: MISERY ramps up the difficulty so play vanilla game first.
This is a link for a video walkthrough of the MISERY mod, and I recomend only watching the first episode for now, more frightening experiences for you to discover: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yiteqlwHX8Y NOTE: Many tips in the video can be applied to the vanilla game.
